editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Squire Oldsapp: OR, THE Night-Adventurers. A COMEDY: As it is Acted at His Royal Highness THE DUKE's Theatre.
div.q: Incidit in Scyllam qui vult vitare Charybdin, Juven.
div.p: LONDON: Printed for Iames Magnes and Richard Bentley, in Russel-street in Covent-Garden, near the Piazza. 1679.

list.head: Drammatis Personae.
list.item: WElford, a wild, debauch'd, Town-Spark. Mr. Betterton.
Henry, his Friend and Companion. Mr. Smith.
Lovell, Friend to Henry. Mr. Crossby.
Squire Oldsapp, a credulous, merry, old, debauch'd Fool, very infirm, yet keeps a Miss for the credit on't. Mr. Nokes.
Sir Fredrick Banter, a Foolish Knight, whose humour is to banter every body. Mr. Leigh.
Colonel Buff, a blunt old Souldier of the last Age. Mr. Sandford.
Pimpo, a sneaking Pimp, (Servant to Tricklove) seemingly religious if not well rewarded, but else very vitious and mercinary. Mr. Vnderhill.
Madam Tricklove, Mistress to Oldsapp, deceitful, mercinary, and cunning. Mrs. Currer.
Christina, Wife to Henry. Mrs. Price.
Sophia, Neice to Christina. Mrs. Barrer.
Cornet, Woman to Tricklove. Mrs. Norrice.
Lucinda, Woman to Christina. Mrs. Seymour.
Constable, Watchmen, Chairmen, Masquers, Servants, and Attendants.

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.l: THough Modish Wit is now as publick grown
As Common Women in this damn'd lew'd Town,
Yet 'tis my Fate, however the World goes,
I'm sure I'm still a Fool in Verse and Prose:
Nay, Poets now (fore George) are at that pass,
They raise their Wits by making me an Ass.
Our Scribler makes me act one of threescore,
A dull, unnatural Fop that keeps a Whore:
Poor silly Rogue—an old Man waggish, fye,
'Tis fitter for an Alderman than I:
However, to oblige and save the Play,
I've undertook this Character to day.
I cannot choose but laugh though cause there's none, ha, ha, ha.
To see the Reverend habit I've on:
And faith I fancy that in being thus fine,
I'm very like too sneaking Friends of mine.
One, Sirs—you'd laugh if you but heard his name,
Is one o'th Burly States at Amsterdam;
Iust of my size, such hait and plodding look,
Such Doublet, such slasht Sleeves, and Knavish Cloak.
T'other's a Velvet blade of Watling-street,
Bred from his infancy to thrive and cheat;
So like me, that for him I've oft been took;
But only mines the more ingenious look.
But as vain Fop gives Gold to silken Whore,
Yet kicks the Thread-bare student from his Door,
Iust of that humour is this factious Fool,
And though for Sneaky he'd disburse his Soul,
He'l grutch a poor clipt Shilling for his Pole.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Welford.
sp.p: WHat! Harry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Dear Iack, thy humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: This was unexpected, i'faith, Prethee when cam'st thou to Town?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: This Morning; and hearing at your Lodgings you were come hither, I had hardly patience to stay and dine, for fear I should miss you, not coming time enough.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: 'Twas a happy fear, and argues friendly love. Well, and how fare all our Friends at Bath? hah! are thy Tenants still thrifty? Does the Old Wood stand where it did: But I think I need not question thee; for I heard of late thou wert grown a great Husband.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Why faith I am so much a Husband, as you call it, to understand that the better the Care, the better the Purse; but my Steward can satisfie you in this particular better than I; for I confess I am of the same temper with other Young Gentlemen, newly come to their Estates, and do not so much consider what I may spend, as what I can spend, still deserting the thrifty for the gentile quality.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: This was thy humour I know; but if I may credit Report; thou art now quite alter'd: Besides, my words carry a double sense with 'em; and by calling thee Husband, I not only meant as to thy Estate, but the other weighty matter, Marriage: Hal. is it so? come, confess.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Why 'faith, I will; and therefore must ingeniously tell thee, one of that soft delicious Sex has been too hard for me; for getting damnably drunk one Night, I got damnably in love too; and was never sober till I was marry'd.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Nay! I expect now you will laugh at me, knowing my former humour of mistrusting all Womens Vertue. But know Friend, this is such a Jewel of a Woman, so witty, so modest, so charming, so observant, so—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Hold! hold! and prethee waste thy Breath in no more of these lavish praises, till thou hast strengthen'd my Faith, in what thou hast said already. Thou talk'st of Miracles, Hal. either of these qualities thou hast mention'd is more than ever any Lady yet had to boast of. But I see thou hast got the blindness of a Husband with his condition. Go home and say thy Prayers. Thou art no Man of this World. Hal.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Yes! and of the next too Sir, let me tell you that, I have gone a good step towards it already. Come prethee desert this roving humour of thine, take a Friends counsel, grow solid, do—grow solid, and marry, 'faith 'tis the sober part of Mans Life—I have consider'd it: you know I have rambled my self ere now, and know what belongs to Mistresses, Garnitures and Fiddles; but by the way, let me tell you, a Mistress breaks a Bone, but a good Wife sets it again. There's a Proverb for ye.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Well, so much for Marriage, Hal. that necessary Ill as many call it. But to requite your Proverb, let me tell ye; a Mistress only cracks a Mans Purse-strings; but a Wife his Heart-strings: Give me thy Hand, I have consider'd that too.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Sir, I grant this may be true in some Cases, your jilting, wanton, costly, squeamish mallapert London Wife, that will be seven years wooing, and use her several Lovers according to her several Humours, I allow may deserve this Character: but mine, although she was bred at Court, and is a Person of Eminent Quality, yet as I have molded her, is now a pretty, humble, good-natur'd, innocent Country Wife, one that will—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: One that will lye with a Man at first sight, and never put him to a seven years Court-ship.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Phoo! Prethee no more o'this; thou art too severe: What a Pox dost think I have marry'd a Messalina! a Dol Common—This is as I fear'd—but I'am resolv'd he shall be ignorant of her being now in Town; I see he cannot leave his old humour.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Well! to confirm the contrary, prethee let me see her; come, I know thou hast brought her to Town with thee.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p:
To Town! That's a good one ifaith: Bring a young breeding Lady to Town, that's the way to have her long for every thing
she sees: no, no! I understand things better than so—Poor Soul, she's at home spinning. She—

sp.speaker: Welf,
sp.p: Spinning! an excellent Employment; and as wholesome and necessary a Debauch for a Woman, as Whoreing and drinking is for a Man. The Wheel is a kind of an implicite Pimp; and while she is whirling it about to spin a fine Thread for her Sheets, it gives her thoughts the liberty of imagining how she shall wear 'em out: Then adding the blunt Stories of the Country Wenches her Companions, and the relish of a Bawdy Song now and then; Oh! 'tis as necessary an exercise as I would wish a Woman.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Hey! why thou art mad sure. Death, is there no difference in Women?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: No faith! that ever I could find; blow but out the Candle—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Then let me inform you the contrary; for mine is the only happy Creature that had power to make me forbear affronting the Sex. But hold—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Hush—He's one of my Creatures, an Utensil I have now and then occasion for—Now Sirrah! what News!

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: News, quoth a! sincerely I am ashamed to tell you; and my Heart bleeds within me, to think you should have no more Consciscience in you. The my Mistriss be a weaker—O, frail Woman! yet you should, methinks, temper your Concupiscence—Sincerely you should, Sir—Fie, fie: I'm asham'd on't; and I begin to think too, that mine is but a scandalous Employment, sincerely.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Sirrah, 'tis a noble one. A Pimp is both an Ancient and Honourable Imploy. What, Rascal, do you murmur at your Vocation? Come—the business—is the Frollick done to night?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Lord, Sir,—have you no Religion! no spice of it in ye: Why if not for my sake, take care of your own Soul, Sir—Take care of your Soul.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Leave your howling, Dog; and tell your message quickly. Sirrah—you could speak softly tother night, when you took my Guinny. Rogue you cou'd.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay! you know my blind side, sincerely: You know I am a mortal Man.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: You talk of Religion, Rascal, Sirrah, don't I know you got a Wench with Child when you liv'd with my Lord Acrelesse—and afterwards contriv'd to have it brought upon the Parish.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I, Sir! 'Twas my Lords Scullion got it: 'Twas none of me, sincerely: I'd have you to know I scorn the scandal. I get her with Child! no: Thank my Education, I am a Maid—I—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: A Maid! a pretious one. Well, whether you did or no, tell me the message quickly, or this shall search for it.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, what you will not murder me, sincerely! will ye?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I know not! do not trust me. Come, Dog, there's half a Crown for ye; say quickly now.—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well! adsniggs Mr. Welford, you are such a confounded Whipster, there is no denying you any thing when you have a mind to know it. Lend me your Ear—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: In the Grove behind my Lord Richlands—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, Sir; but you must make haste, for 'tis near the time.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: You are sure the Old Fellow will not fail—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Very sure, Sir; his discourse for above this week has been nothing but hard Words, Charms and Conjurations, and has such a mind to be young again, that he misses not a tittle, sincerely.—You are wag to use him so, y'are, y'are: but gad mend ye, gad mend ye.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Go, Sirrah; prepare every thing, and tell her I'll be there immediately. Go, Rascal—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: What, an Intrigue, Iack! I told you I knew that Fellows Business by his Face.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Prethee, do not abuse the Poor Fellow; for he's as necessary in this affair to me, as he that gave thy Wife at Church was to thee. But see, yonder's Will. Lovel, and the rest of the Bowlers; there's some humours amongst them, that will divert thee, Hall—Prethee excuse me now, because I have a little business—But thou knowest my Old Lodging: to morrow I'm thine all day.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: No; 'tis resolv'd he must not see, nor know my Wife, while she is in Town.

div.stage: Enter William Lovel, Sir Fredrick, Colonel Buff.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Hal; I am all wonder to find thee here. I heard thou wert marry'd, and had'st resolv'd to desert all thy old Friends in Town.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: No such matter, Sir, a Wife will hardly get such power over me—I am my Friends all day, tho' I am hers at night, Will.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Colonel, you were talking of Toledo's, here's one for you, look upon't; look upon't again, Colonel; you have look't, you have survey'd it well?

sp.speaker: Col. Buff.
sp.p: I have, Sir Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p:
Well, now take it and run me through with't; pshaw,
what a Man of Blood, and sflinch—Do it, I say. Run me through, I've a trick in't—

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: By the Life of St. Gregory, Sir Fredrick; what mean ye, are you compos Mentis?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Look now: He has spoil'd my trick, quite ruin'd my device, by King Ieffery. Why Colonel, if you had run me through, gad I would have shown you the most cunning trick, the most intricate sophistick matter, that ever Eyes beheld: I wou'd have caus'd Sack, Rhenish, and Claret to have gusht from the Wound; I wou'd have made you drunk by transpiration, with a box on the Ear made you sober again, heal'd up the Orrifice in a trice, and then gone to Supper with the Pox—Not run a Man through, when he desires you?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Hey day! Here's a pleasant humour ifaith; prethee what is he?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Why the only Buffoon of Town and Country, Sir Fredrick Banter; one that has spent the best part of his youth in observing and practising the ridiculous humours of the age, and the more mimicry he has in his Actions, the more he thinks himself accomplish't: a great bowler: but amongst all his humours this of bantring people he most delights in.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Bantering, prithee what's that?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Bantring in his sense is divided two ways; one is a manner of gabling, by doubling the Tongue; which makes you think they tell a story, when they say nothing: And th' other, is telling ye a prolix, ridiculous, incredible story, with the face of truth, answering your question with a tedious lye; and the jest is in amuzing you half an hour, in hearing an impertinent, prodigious narration of wonderful matters, full of non-sence, and far from the purpose—See, he's at it, prithee observe him—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Colonel, I know you are a Man in favour, and if you would but—bublinshrundish—the same again, the oblishbrutiglish would advantage the—whishmstolshed in the greatest manner imaginable.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: What would you have me do, Sir Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Why look you, I say you are a Man much belov'd at Court: Now, what were it for you to wshilbeminishiemdlidge the King, about infedgingldgninry upon apprehension to usludingell grindidliddintolwish—in kindness to your friend.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: I beg a Pention of the King, d'e say?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: No, no: I don't talk of Pention, I say; pray observe me, I say were it my case as 'tis yours; I would subberlinledge ningldruidge to any Friend, and then, mergnmurgnledg and the worth prilugillux coming in! Gad I would.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: What, Sir! why, what a Devil don't you understand me?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: By the Blade, not a word, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, dost not! give me thy hand then, I have a little imperfection! ha, ha. Will. didst hear me?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir. Now, is it not as I told thee?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, and I find he's much taken with it! but, by Sir Fredricks leave though, I should sooner break his head than stay so long to let him break his jest, were I the Person. But prithee are there any. such people?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O many Sir, I assure you—Tis a very Modish humour now adayes—That other there is a Colonel of the last age, an honest merry blunt Fellow, a little vain, if you get into his Element of fighting, but else a very good companion—But the best of our company is wanting, one 'Squire Oldsap, a credulous merry old debaucht fool, one that tho' he be too crazy himself for Women, yet he keeps a Wench for the credit on't. The pleasant'st threescore and three thou ever saw'st—Pla—Faith this was good luck, yonder he comes, prithee observe him, Hal.

div.stage: Enter Oldsap with a Fools Cap on's head, and a Bundle under his arm.

sp.speaker: Oldsap.
sp.p: Lovel, merry be thy heart Lad, my Son, Son of the Ooldsaps, I'll call thee so, shall I? For a Man that keeps his word with me shall not onely be my Son, but my Sons Son, nay my Sons Sons Grandson! if affinity will do't—hah, Sir Fredrick, by the Marry Maskins I'll kiss thee too. Prince.—Prince of the Jokers, prithee let me kiss thy hoof, do—let me, my Merry wagg—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: By King Iesfery, by no means, Squire. Well, but a pox on thee, how dost thou do, Old Jewstrump?

div.stage: [Gives him a blow on the Head.

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: Very well, Sir Fredrick! Very well! better and better! by the Marry Maskins,—whoop,—why who's here—what my noble old Friend Col. Buff too, let me kiss thee, old stump of honour: Before George I could jump for joy to see thee: hah! old Lad?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Whirr! why this is Whirligigg.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The mock of Regeneration? but hush, we shall have more yet.

sp.speaker: Col. Buff.
sp.p: Gramercy Squire ifaith! I see thou art a merry shaver still, by the Blade, thou hold'st out bravely. But prithee, my merry spawn of the Oldsapp's what dost thou mean by this, this Cap here? Thou art not going a Morrice-dancing, art thou?

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: A Morice-Dancing! why merry be thy heart Colonel, what Jokes upon me,—hah,—before George tis well I am in hast I should pound you else, by the marry maskins I should—This Cap, Sir, let me tell you, was—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: I'll tell you what 'twas Colonel. I was acquainted with't before him. This Cap, Colonel, was the Cap of Fortunatus, the wishing-Cap. You have heard of the wishing-Cap, han't you?

sp.speaker: Col. Buff.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard of some such thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis very well known abroad. 'Tis i'th' Chronicle. This Cap Colonel; (Mercy upon us who wou'd imagine it?) This Cap has been the death of many a Bishop.

sp.speaker: Col. Buff.
sp.p: A Bishop! Sir Fredrick! Marry Heav'n forbid, how?

sp.speaker: Sir. Fred.
sp.p: Why they dy'd Sir, no one knows how—but they dy'd—The very lining on't had like to broke the Heart of two or three Queens.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible! why, good Sir Fredrick? what vertue can there be in the Lining of this Cap?—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: O wonderful, wonderful: 'Twill draw Teeth, that's one thing.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Teeth!

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ay, or cure the Gout; the New Spring is nothing to't.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Pish, ye jest, ye jest, I'll ne'r believe it.

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: Well, said Sir Fredrick, you are full of your merry humours I see; but take it from me, this is no jesting matter: for let me tell you, how slightly soever you think of it, this same Cap here is worth Two Millions in Money.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: What the Devil does he banter how?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Two Millions! how, prethee Squire, how?

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: How! why there's Magick in't. 'Tis full of Magick; 'twas the Cap of Michael de Scoto: The Florentîne Necromancer, and with the rest of his Robes, which I have here in this Bundle, together with some Ceremonies which shall be nameless, has power to convert Age into Youth—You shall see me to morrow a Spark of one and twenty.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Ay, you may fancy what you will, Mr. Oldsapp, but by the Blade I can find no reason in what you say.

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: Reason! before George, the Colonel is a little soft too. Why, 'tis Magick: 'tis Magick, Man: 'tis above Reason: Lord, how dull he is.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Confound 'um, these are the most insufferable Coxcombs: I shall never have patience—

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: I have told my Sneaky on't already, and poor Rogue she's so overjoyed—she has such hopes of me, poor Quean. Well I'll about it instantly. And pray believe that nothing but so pressing an affair could take me from my merry Bowlers. But to morrow, like Iupiter, and Mars, and Mercury: Venus, Diana, and the rest of the Gods, I will appear and frollick and frollick my merry wags;—to try, to try,—ah Rogues! well adieu.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ah, go thy ways old Baboon. Well, by King Ieffry, 'tis a strange thing men should be such Fools.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Come Sir Fredrick, let's go in and drink a Bottle before we bowl, ifaith my Westwhaphlia, at Dinner, has made me as dry as dust.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: With all my heart, Col. Will. Lovel, wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll follow you, Sir. Come Hal, wilt thou make one? I'm sure thou canst not meet with better diversion.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: No: a pox on't, I am weary of 'em already: for I am as much tired with the extravagance of a Fool, as with riding of a jaded Hackney. Besides I am weary, and will go presently to Bed; but to morrow I'll see thee again.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Farewel, Hal.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Welford, Madam Tricklove, and Pimpo.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: WELL, confess now; art not you a wicked, lewd, debauch'd wretch, to hire a Fellow to put such a trick upon the poor Old Man, and now to stay here thus with me, for any thing I know upon some ill design.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: And are not you a cunning, vile, deceitful Damsel, not to tell the Old Dotard of the Cheat, when you knew of it, and could have betray'd me: but now to dare to send for me; ifaith I fear, intending some outrage upon my Person: Hah, are not you a Wicked Wretch?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Sincerely: The truth is you are both wicked Wretches: and I'm afraid the Devil will have ye, that's in short. First, for cozening my old Master. Secondly, for polluting your self. And thirdly, and principally, for abusing a Man of such eminent parts as I am. But such whipsters as you, are too hot to have any consideration, sincerely.—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Why, Dog! are you murmuring again? I have not had ashillings worth yet of your moldy conscience for my half-Crown, and are you at your reproofs already?—but I'le—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A treacherous grumbling Rogue! Cut's throat, cut's throat.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, ay! his throat. Carve him, Carbonado him. His throat, quoth a—hold, hold, Sir—what mean ye?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Sirrah! Swear! swear desperately too, to be true to the intrigue, and do what you are commanded, or I will rip ye up from the Navel to the Nose.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Hold, hold: I will, I will—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p:
Swear then, not one of your sneaking equivocating Phanatick Oaths, such as oddsniggs! by the Mass! odsniggers, and the like.
But a good Heroick, Romantick Oath. Sirrah, let me see, swear by the Sun, and Moon, and seven Stars.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: O Profane, Monstrous, Irreligious; is not the seven Stars enough, but you must bring the Sun and Moon upon the Stage too? sincerely it smiteth my Conscience: and I had rather swear Muggleton's Oath—by Sodom and Gomorrah, than swear by the Sun and Moon—I had sincerely—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Do't, Sirrah; or expect what follows. Come say, by the Sun, and Moon, and seven Stars.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: By the Sun, and Moon, and seven Stars—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I'll do't—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well, I'll do't; but odsniggars, Mr. Welford, if ever I take you at an advantage—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: How, Rascal, odsniggers after such an Oath? What an offence is this?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, a horrid offence indeed—why, Sir,—will you give a Man no liberty of Conscience! sincerely, I did it to give a relish to my Mouth, after the other lewd Execration.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: A Pox O' your Chilblain Conscience. But hark, I think I hear one coming.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: 'Tis my old Master.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: So, I see he keeps touch; you have plac'd the Fellows ready, Madam.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: All ready; I instructed them this Morning—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Come, let's be gone then: Sirrah, you know your Business.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, I do know my Business, and will follow it: I'll go home and read a Chapter—Sincerely you shall find Pimpo another manner of Man than you take him for.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Why, Dog, Sun of a Whore, you will not forswear your self, will ye?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Not I, Sir; I only spoke of the Sun and Moon in Cheapside; I did not swear—and sincerely, Mr. Welford, I do not understand your hide and seek, not I: nor shall you impose upon my Judgment, Sir.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Your Judgment, Baboon! This damn'd Rogue knows he has me on the hip: Well, Sirrah, there's another half Crown for you, see if you can afford me a better Pennyworth now—Come, let's go—We shall be seen anon, and spoil all—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: So; this is something yet; 'tis a strange thing! now my Conscience that was within this Minute as narrow as the Muzzle of a Trumpet, is as wide as from hence to Aldgate: Certainly this mettle has Witchcraft in't—for a Key of Gold shall open an Iron-Lock, tho' the Devil thrust his horn into the Key-hole. Well—I must do't—here he comes, now for the conjuration—

sp.speaker: Oldsapp.
sp.p: O, Pimpo!

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: O, Sir, I am glad you are come, sincerely; the hour is almost past.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh! I would not have it past for the World.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Nor I neither, Sir; come unstrip, unstrip, have you got all your things ready?—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ay, ay,—here in this Bundle: Oh, if the Charm be but strong enough, Pimpo, I shall be made for ever.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, my Mistress will be overjoy'd to find such alteration.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha;—ay, so she will poor Rogue, I warrant she'll be transported.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Look, I have got all my things ready; first, here's my Circle, in this I am to conjure up Concupisence in the likeness of a Water-Rat.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Then here's my dead Mouse, and my couple of Snails, to invoke the Queen of Fairies. And this is my Sirrup of Cacademons, to annoint my Face with.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Olds.
Pimp.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, have a care of that: sincerely 'twill spoil all; besides, Sir, under favour, you have but a scurvy voice, and from you any thing will be like a Godly Tune, 'twill be all one.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: I think so too; for, the truth is, as thou sayst, Pimpo, my Voice is not extraordinary. But come then, bind my Head and Hands, and annoint my Face, that we may begin.—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir—so now kneel down, Sir, and wink—nh nh—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Keep it from my Mouth as much as thou canst, for tho' the Vertue on't be extraordinary, it hath but an ill taste.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: There—let me look on ye now: ha! odsniggs, what do I see? what Miracles are these?

sp.speaker: Olds
sp.p: Hah, what sayst thou, Miracles?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Why Sir—you are grown monstrous fair.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, am I?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Sincerely, I am amaz'd at it; how! how d'ye feel your self, Sir?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p:
Why, before George, very brisk; and methinks four or
five of the hairs of my Beard are fall'n away o'th' sudden.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well, Sir; There's your Wand, and I'll go aside and pray for you.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh prethee do not talk of Pray'r, Man; the Devil will be angry then, and make me older than I am.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll be careful. Odsnigs I shall laugh out.
sp.stage: Oldsapp waves his Wand, and then sings.
sp.l: Draw near ye Spirits, that dispence
Your Pow'rs or'e Concupiscence;
Bring all your Spells, and come along,
To make an amorous Old Man young!
Whose frozen Ioints, long since have cool'd his passion,
But now he sighs, and blows, and puffs, for generation;
Come, come away; your assistance confer,
And then I shall be tho happ • est Old Cur,
The happiest Old Cur in the Nation.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hark, now the great Devil is whistling the young Cubbs together—Ohhow I tremble!
sp.stage: Waves his Wand, and Pimpo, and they within, make a horrid whirstling.
Loud laughing within, and this Song.
sp.l: How frail is old age to believe
Their, Sinnews can even be strong.
or think that a heap
of Diseases can reap
The Pleasures of him that is young.

lg.l: He plunges in care let him do what he can,
So wretched a thing is a doting Old Man.
His Life has been spent in Debauch,
Till he comes to be sixty or more,
And so wenches on
Till his vigor is gone,
And then the Old Letcher gives o're.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: A passion that's sickly can never be strong;
And an old doting Fool is far worse than a young.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What's this I hear? do they mock me?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh, what shall I do? I have mist something now, and the Devils laugh at me for it.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh, oh, murder, murder.

div.stage: [Pimpo cries out as if he were hurt.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: That was Pimpo's Voice—Oh I am in an Ague.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Whiz, buz, bough.

div.stage: [Takes a Rope, and ties Oldsapp to a Tree.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh, good Devil, avoid Satan; sweet Devil, do not hurt; avoid Satan, avoid; Oh, oh,—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh, I'm murder'd, I'm murder'd, they have me by the Nose: oh, oh—So, there's Love ty'd to a Tree.

And now to my young Whipster, that lyes yonder in the Bed of Honour; there's half a Guinney more at least, Well, 'tis a pretty employment this, ifaith—if a Man carries policy with it, and sincerely is more in use, than People imagine. But they want my skill to wheadle and sooth iniquity—ah, Signior Pimpo is a brave Fellow at it.
sp.l: For to connive at Crimes and vile Transgression,
Is the best rule for one of my Profession.

div.stage: Enter Henry, Christina, Sophia, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: IF you would give me no cause to doubt your love or obedience, be careful of this particular, and let no one know of our Marriage, or that you are in Town, till I give you further notice. I have some reasons, which I may not discover, which force me to be thus strict with you: But, my Dear, 'tie for thy good, assure thy self.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I confess, I am wholly ignorant of your design, and therefore can say little to the Business: But what will my Friends think, when they know I am in Town, and have not so much kindness as to come and see 'em; did not you promise me I should have the priviledge to see all my Relations—and do what I would?—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p:
I acknowledge I did; but there has something fell out since,
which has made me alter my resolution: Prethee have but a little patience, and thou shalt see 'em all.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: But hark ye, Sir, to come nearer to the matter, are not you infected with the Epidemick Disease of Mankind, Jealousie?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Jealousie! prethee Cozen; what, I jealous?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: This prohibition seems to imply as much; but, if you are, 'tis no Crime as the World goes now: For, a Man of this Age can no more forbear being jealous, (if his Wife be handsome) than one of the last could forbear living from her, if she were old or ugly—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Faith a good observation; why, now I see thou hast lov'd Songs and Play-Books thus long for something: But, my pretty pert Kinswoman, give me leave to tell you, I am no such jealous Coxcomb; I have too good a knowledge of my person and sufficiency to be jealous, I thank ye—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I must confess that is an excellent rule for prevention; but, here is another weighty question to be resolv'd: for, suppose now that she should not be so well satisfi'd in your person and sufficiency; what then, Sir? what then?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Faith that's enough to make a Man jealous indeed: But, what sayst thou to that, my dear?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I never doubted any thing; nor can any Disease (accident or misfortune) whatsoever, abate any of my affection: I love ye so well, that 'tis impossible I should ever think ill of ye, were ye never so wicked.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ah—poor Soul—ay—here's a Wise now—well—when thou art dead, I'll have thee canoniz'd for a Saint.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Hah—when she's dead—perform the part of a loving Husband; and to convince her that you are not jealous—constrain not your Wife to keep within doors—for, a Woman that's forc'd to keep her Beauties unseen, will spend ye 200 l. a year in getting Pictures drawn, in little, to send abroad to her Friends.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Very well—you have a great deal of Judgment, I see.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ay, a little—I have not read Songs, Romances, and Play-Books so long for nothing, you know. Then, first, buy her a Glass-Coach that she may be seen in; do; a Glass-Coach—do, I say.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Bless me; this prating Jilt, will perswade me out of my Reason. Prethee, impertinence, leave me: a Glass-Coach, in the Devils name! Come, come, my dear, let's go.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, here's Mr. Lovel coming down the walk, and another with him.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Death, he'll see us presently; come, come away.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Don't go, Cozen; what, does he think to make Nuns of us? I say we will see the Man.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: But I say you shall not; do not provoke me—but go—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Come—prethee do not vex him—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Vex him! well I'll go; but if I be not reveng'd—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Sirrah, go you home with 'em, and excuse my absence at Dinner; and take a particular notice, who has access to 'em; and about nine a Clock at Night, bid the Fellows bring the Sedan up to the Cock in Bow-street.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: Yes, Sir—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: I think she's vertuous, and I have reason to think so. However, I am resolv'd to keep her conceal'd, till my business is done, and then, watch her, as I see occasion; but here comes Lovel, and the Devil I think with him; no matter, I am for no drinking match these two hours. I have business.

div.stage: Enter Lovel, and Oldsapp as newly unti'd from the Tree.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; By Heav'n, Squire, this is the strangest adventure; all this Night ty'd to a Tree, say you?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ay, before George, have I; and been almost drown'd with the Rain; besides the fright the dancing Devils put me to, when they ty'd me up.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, by your Face, a Man would guess you had been in the Devils Company, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: My Face! well, that makes me some amends however.—And prethee how is't, am I taking, hah—how dost like my countenance?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, pray guess, Sir, guess; for my part, I have not wit enough to speak my admiration.

sp.speaker: Oldsap.
sp.p: Why, this is a Devil!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Copy of him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: And I am the same Old Fellow, I used to be, am I?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The very same, only a little alter'd in complexion.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Complexion in the Devils name—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Or else I see no difference.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why then the Conjurer's a Dog—and I'm resolv'd I'll go instantly and take the Law of him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, have a care of that, Sir, the Law's chargeable.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p:
I care not: I'll do't: for I'm as implacable as an angry Fish-Wife that has catcht the Fellow that pickt her Pocket. For, first I'll have his Ears nayl'd to the Pillory, for perjury: Then I'll bring him
within the Statute of Witchcraft; and have him hang'd without benefit of Clergy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Faith—I must needs say 'twas a great affront, and a grand imposition upon a Man of your quality; besides, I think, Sir, you are never the younger neither.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why no; wou'd I were hang'd if I find any alteration at all.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: VVhy, what ill luck is that? but certainly, Sir, there must be more in this business than you imagine: Nor does the affront only lye upon the Fellow. Pray, Sir, who brought you to this Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Iack Welford; thou knowest him, one of our Brother Bowlers.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: There, there lyes the plot—'tis plain, Sir; why, to my knowledge he has been in love with your Mistress this half year and more, and who knows but this may be a trick upon you, by his means.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: VVhat he in love with my Sneaky!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, that I can assure you; why did you never take notice on't—Did you never see 'em together—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Yes, often, but I never doubted any thing: for before George, I always took him for a very honest Fellow.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: VVhy, Sir, who doubts it—he is so—a very honest Fellow; and tho' he lies with your VVife, your Sister, your Aunt, your Kinswoman, your Mistress—your—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: The Devil and all—my Mistress, before George: that word enraged me beyond all patience: and he shall know, that invading a Man's Propriety in his Mistress is Death by Wenching Law—and he deserves the stab—I'll murder him instantly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, know me so much your Friend that if my Sword and Arm can do you any service to revenge your wrongs you shall command me.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Sir, I thank ye; but I've another way to work with him, which shall be done suddenly—and so farewel. But hark ye, if you'l do me the favour to let me see you at my House this Evening—I have a secret to deliver to you, in which you may sensibly oblige me: Till then I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I will not fail ye. Happy minute!

Fortune in this is more my Friend than ever; for I have long lov'd this VVoman, but he keeps her so close, that I could never get access to her, and that he should introduce me: 'tis a pleasant one ifaith, my disclosing Welfords Intrigue furthers my own design; for when he's remov'd, I have more freedom: 'Tis not so like a Friend, but 'tis like a Man of pleasure, and that's the rule I must walk by—

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Welford, Madam Tricklove, and Pimpo.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: WHY, Sir, I tell you once more: I found him gone, unty'd and gone—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: How was't possible, Rascal, he could get loose if you had plaid the faithful Servant, and ty'd him last enough?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by that; but if a new Rope, strong enough to hang us all, could tye him fast enough, I am sure I did it—ah would it were to do again, I would think better on't sincerely—

sp.speaker: M. Trickl.
sp.p: And so would I; you should not get such power over me if it were to do again.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: What has this notorious, dissembling Rascal, taught you a fit of the Conscience too? Faith, I am more in love with the humour than ever; it shews thee a discreet ingenious Woman; and such a one, if she has a scruple arises in her Conscience, which is very seldom, it shall be sure to be after the business is done, for then she is at leisure.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Well, I swear Mr. Welford, this insulting temper of yours will lessen my love to you; what Woman could bear this, especially from a Man that has had so many evident proofs of my kindness, as you have?

sp.speaker: Welf. Nay,
sp.p: rather than put you to the trouble of squeezing out a tear, I will confess my self ungrateful: but here's a Rascal, that tho' he looks like a Fifth-Monarchy-Man, and talks like a Quaker, has a Conscience tougher than a Buck-Skin; is a greater Atheist than a Bully that owns it his profession; and for mischief—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: What mischief, Sir, what mischief, sincerely I am asham'd to hear you talk thus; and wonder how you can have the face to abuse an honest, worthy person thus: For, as great a Rascal, as you make of him; there are some Gentlemen, that shall be nameless, are glad to keep him company, and thank him too, when they have occasion to make use of his parts.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ay, Sirrah; a Rascal, like a Bullet, is then only necessary when we intend to do mischief: but what excuse canst thou have for thy last pranck: didst not thou tye thee poor old Gentleman to a Tree? was not that a great Crime?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: And did not you in the mean time lye with his Mistress? was not that a greater Crime?

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: How, Sirrah, with me, why thou impudent, ugly, impertinent, sneaking, dissembling, cheating, lying, Son of a Whore—ud's life, lend me your Sword, that I may cut his Nose off—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Nay, nay, if she be provok'd, 'tis time to run; sincerely I had rather lye at the mercy of a Thunder-Bolt—and less harm 'twou'd do me.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—'tis such an old Rascal: but I think 'tis best for me to consider of my safety; for if the old Fellow is got loose, there's no staying for me here; thou knowest 'tis now almost Night—and he cannot be long absent—besides I want Linen.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: Madam, Sir Fredrick Banter, and Colonel Buff, came into the House unknown to me, and are just coming up.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Pox take Sir Fredrick, run and tell him I am not within.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Madam, I did tell him so—but he told me I ly'd; he heard your Voice.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: A Devil o' your diligence.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Sir Fredrick! Oh for Heavens sake, Madam, let me go; I would not have him see me here for the World—

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Death and Confusion! what makes him here to disturb me?

div.stage: Enter Sir Fredrick, Col. Buff, and Pimpo.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Madam, sweet Madam, your humble and devoted Servant. Colonel—come, now your Honour.

sp.speaker: Col. Buff.
sp.p: Your Servant, Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Well said, the Colonel is a Souldier, Madam, you must pardon his behaviour.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Any thing, Sir, rather than give you the trouble of repeating it. You, Rogue, are the cause of this—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ah! I see by her looks she's vext at their being here; but it's all one, she shall find I can resent an affront: She shall, sincerely.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Sirrah, do you think that I'll ever put up this injury?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: And do you think that I'll exercise my learned faculty for nothing?

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p:
Nothing, Rascal, do all mine and Mr. Welford's Gifts
amount to nothing? bedsies the Sallary I give; which, since you can forget, Sirrah—I'll give you some cause for it, and from this moment will pay it no longer.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well, if you will pay no longer, sincerely—I'll pimp no longer; and so your Friend and Servant: But, hold, now I think on't, I'll stay till Mr. Welford comes, because he owes me an Angel.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: An Angel! for what?

sp.speaker: Pimp
sp.p: Why for some service done Yesterday; Lord, you are mighty forgetful: Come, come, Madam—places are not so scarce, that a Min of my industry should want; here's a Person of Quality not far off, that to my knowledge will be glad of me, and give my Function due recompence; there is Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Madam—my carnest desire to see you, with a little other Business, which the Colonel in due time shall deliver to you, made me guilty of this rudeness.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: I am in such a confusion, and so tortur'd in my thoughts for Welford—I hear not one word they say—what were you saying, Sir Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Sir. Fred.
sp.p: Why, did you not hear me, Madam, did not you hear me? Faith I'll banter her—why I was saying, Madam, that if Mr. Welford had made his address to the Mogul, before the Cattamountains of Padua had taken their degree, th' Alarm had been given to the Swedes, from the Swedes to the Switzers, and then the Pomegranates had streight been taken out of the mouth of the Turks, and given to the Germans, a plain case; and then Champaign had been twelve-pence a Bottle by this time.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: No Minute; but just at such a time: Well, Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: What then? hey day—if she should banter me all this while, 'twere a good jest—

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Fredrick, that again; I confess my thoughts were a little busie.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: You are melancholly, Madam; I see you are out of humour, I can guess the cause too; but fear nothing, Madam, all shall be well again: Pray be merry—Come the Colonel shall give you a Song, do old Pot-gun; sing the Battle of Mardike.

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: Oh no more o' that, good Sir Fredrick; for my part I am no Songster—that's a good one indeed—why, when did you know a Souldier sing well, unless it were to a Trumpet, or a Drum?

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Was ever Creature so tortur'd? Pray then, Sir, since you cannot sing, and that I know the business of you Men of War with Visitants, is only to divert 'em with a Story; let me desire the favour to hear from your own mouth, your own actions in the War, I know 'tis the best thing you can talk of, and the strangeness of it I doubt not will divert me too—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Now, Colonel, charge her, she's in thy Province, charge her I say, old Pollux; hark ye; shew her the Shot in thy Groin.

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: Pish, Madam; leaving the story of my life for some fitter opportunity, give me leave first to inform you of something that concerns you.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Concern me! sure this old Mortar-piece knows nothing of my Intrigue, does he? Concern me!

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: Nearly, Madam; Mr. Oldsap is this night engag'd in a Rencounter; Sir Fredrick and I heard of it at the Tavern just now from Will. Lovel—who I believe is concern'd?

sp.speaker: M. Trick,
sp.p: A Rencounter! if my Welford should be there now; oh how my heart akes—

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: But the main person aim'd at, is Mr. Welford—

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Oh, Gods! what do I hear?

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: For my part, they are both my Friends; and therefore I would have a prevention—Pray, Madam, view this Sword—

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Hell and Death, I am distracted; who's within there? who's there? are you all deaf?

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: Madam—by your leave a little, pray handle this Sword—

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Burn the Sword, would it were rusty to the Hilt: Oh this Witch too; whither is she gone?

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: What's that, rusty—ha, ha, ha—but I must bear with her, she's a little simple: rusty quoth a—'Sbud, the Nation would be in a fine condition if this Sword were suffer'd to be rusty.

div.stage: [Sir Fred. is bantring Pimp. all this while.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: From the Moon say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: From the World in the Moon.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: A Whale as big as all Garnsey.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Bigger, bigger.

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—he's bantring the poor Fellow.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Mercy upon us; what prodigies are these? and yet I warrant, maugre all this, our wilful Nation will keep on in their sinful courses still.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ay, the more's the pity; but tis well he's taken—for he has done a world of mischief.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Has he so?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Oh, ay, he had like to have swallowed the Isle of Wight.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: The Isle of Wight, sure never was the like known—I never heard a word on't till now—'tis not in Muddiman's Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Oh no, he's lazy, the Gazet out-does him; but you shall have some Figure-flinger or other cast the Nativity on't; when new Almanacks come in season.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Very strange! but pray, an't like your worship, How comes this Whale hither?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Why, in a Hand-Bakset.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: A Hand-Basket! look, look, thou starest now! Spinola's Hand-Basket—Fool Made purposely in the Moon for this occasion. And some Astrologers hold, that this is Spinola's Whale too—and design'd by the Mogul of the Moon, a present to the French King, that his Army might have Oil to their Sallets—

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—by the Blade—a pleasant humour.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well, this must portend something; for I never heard of a Whale in my Life, but that some body or other dy'd presently after.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Come hither, and give me thy hand; Colonel, your company too—hum dost thou see this here—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Within this little Vessel is contain'd Steruntatorium Mivaculosum, or, The Powder of Sciences—hast a mind to be learned, wilt thou speak Greek?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, 'tis not for my profit to be a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: No! Well then, dost thou love singing?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh extreamly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Dost thou? here, take then, take, thou shalt do't to a Miracle: Tarlton shall be nothing to thee. Come, snuff up—there—come now, begin, try, try—oh—weak, weak; tother touch—
There now, sing, ha, ha, ha, go thy ways I'll warrant thee for a Songster.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Sincerely, methinks—'tis but a scurvy—tune—tho'—o'my Nose—my Nose—

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Oh, for Heaven's sake go and part 'em; yonders my Master and Mr. Welford fighting in the Street, and my Mistress is run out like one distracted,

sp.speaker: C. Buff.
sp.p: 'Tis so; come Sir Fredrick, I am resolv'd there shall be no foul play—

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Welford, pursued by Oldsapp, and more.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: NO Sense of Honour, Dogs?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Down with the Traytor, down with him; kill him, kill him.

div.stage: [Henry is carry'd in a Sedan cross the Stage.

sp.speaker: Henr.

div.stage: Enter Will. Lovel, with the Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yonder, they are; go quickly, and do your office—
Tho' Welford is my Rival, he's a Gentleman, and 'tis baseness to suffer him to be beset: But I must keep this from the Old Fellow's knowledge—lest it spoil my design—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: 'Twas well the Watch came and disperst 'em, I had certainly been mauld else: This Old Fellow has discovered my Intrigue with his Mistress; and, if I should consider seriouly of the matter, this affair of his is neither contrary to Reason nor Justice. Would I were at home—I am very dry, and very drowsie; and 'tis so dark, that I hardly know the way to my Lodging—how now, what's there a Chair! ay, 'tis so, and by those Fellows standing there, it should be empty too—I'll make use of this opportunity—It may be by this means I may light on some pleasant adventure, to recompence my Nights trouble—I am resolv'd to venture.

sp.speaker: 1 Chairman.
sp.p: Iak, Iack, Master's come back again.

sp.speaker: 2 Chairman.
sp.p: Is he come! then let's make haste.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: So, they take me for their Master; thus far I am right: now Fortune be propitious—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p:
The Bullies are surpriz'd by the Watch, and the Gentleman has made his escape; who it was I know not, but by his demeanour, he should be of quality. Dogs! Night Rogues! is this a
time for Rencounters—Here—Hey! where are ye? bring the Chair hither—Hey—what gone? What damn'd Rascals are these? afraid I believe the Watch should seize on 'em—what shall I do? I shall never find the way home, 'tis so dark: How now, who's this?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Tis he! 'tis he. Oh my dear, how glad am I to find thee! ye naughty Rogue to leave me so; but see what comes on't: yet for all that, I am glad with all my heart I have thee again. My dear, dear—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis a loving poor Rogue, who ere 'tis; and I hope young.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, come away with me, for the Old Fellow and a Company of Bullies are watching for thee; and I love thee too well, to have thee kill'd.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Who it is I know not, but such a tempting occasion I must follow—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, come in with me, and I'll hide you in my Chamber, till the search be over.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Dear Matrimony, thou must pardon me; for this is such a pleasant adventure, that I cannot choose but be in love with—
sp.l: But tho I to th' Banquet hungry go,
'Twould spoil my Stomach, if my Spouse should know.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I swear I tremble to think on't.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Expect never to be happy then: Prethee Cozen, take my Council, and believe that a jealous Husband, that takes all the liberty imaginable, and allows his Wife none, will at last pretend a suspicion of your Intrigue, only to keep you from the knowledge of his.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I have consider'd it, and am resolv'd to let him know, I have enough of the Woman to resent such an injury.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: For my part I'll assist you in all your proceedings, and if we two han't enough of the old Serpents subtilty to confound the Intrigues of one weak unthinking man; 'tis pity but our Sex was chang'd, and we made the dullest of Creatures—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: It distracts me to think on his behaviour: what business can he have out thus late—
How now! is he come?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, the Sedan is just coming in at the Gate.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Go then, prethee Cozen, be not seen to Night, it may be he's in drink, and a reproof now will signifie nothing.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: True: for a drunken man is as perverse a Creature, as an opinionated old man—whatever he's advis'd, he's sure to do quite contrary: Therefore, 'tis best to leave him till the morning qualm—for then a little impertinence will teaze him more than ordinary—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Now to prepare my self with a little policy—I must pout and seem angry, as, if consider'd rightly, the cause requires; for, to live as singly after we have ventur'd upon Marriage as we did before—in truth is unreasonable. Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: H • ! a stranger! Heaven! what means this?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I have now reason to bless my adverse fortune, since it has requited me with so beautiful an Object; and I see there are some happy Stars that—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, no more of this; but tell me where my Husband is, and by what means you got possession of his Chair?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Her Husband! that's well—
Faith, Madam, y' have done me an injury in interrupting my thanks to Fortune—I was horribly afraid I should have rambled all Night—and truly such a Lodging deserves a little acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: A Lodging! truth, Sir, y'are deceiv'd: y'are like to get no Lodging here—But where have you left my Husband—you look not like a Murderer—or else I should think y'had kill'd him, to put some horrid design in execution—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p:
Not I faith—I found the Chair empty, and went into it; and being mistaken by the good, honest, purblind, Sons of Whores the Chair-men for another—I suppose, am brought hither
instead of your Husband—and I am resolv'd I'll not baulk my Fortune—I—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Then, Sir, let me desire you to be gone before he comes, for his being left so, must needs make him very angry; and then his finding you here, will be enough to make an everlasting breach betwixt us—good Sir, go—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Not I—faith Madam—I must beg your pardon—I will not stir—come what will on't—'tis a pretty place—this—and yonder's a good Bed, I see—your Servant Madam; to morrow morning command me any thing—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: A strange blunt Fellow this.
Pray, Sir, no more trifling, but go; my reputation is more dear to me, than your inconvenience; therefore be gone, or I am resolv'd to cry out.—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Nay, now I am sure you won't; for I'll no more believe a Woman intends to cry out, that says she will, than I'll believe a Man has courage to duel me, that draws upon me in the Play-house—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: A strange confidence this; what d'e intend, Sir?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: 'Faith, to go to Bed; I want no waiters in these cases: I am a true adventurer, Madam, and like a Knight Errant am contented with my Quarters, where-ever I find 'em.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Why, sure you won't go to the Bed that's prepar'd for my Husband?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Yes, but I will—and be thankful too, I like the place very well.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Nay, this is rudeness unheard of; good Sir, consider my condition, and what danger I am in, if my Husband comes, as I'm certain he will to night—kind, sweet Sir—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Pox on her, she has mollify'd me: Well, Madam, two conditions observ'd, perhaps I may depart. The first is, to tell me who you are? and secondly, to permit me to wait on you to morrow.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Sir, the latter of these I will consent too; but to discover my name, for some private reasons, I am bound not to do.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Then here I pitch my Tent—pugh—you cannot be so cruel, to turn me out of Doors at this unreasonable time of night, when nothing is abroad but Owles and Weezles.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.l: What shall I do?
If he's found here, I am ruin'd—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I'll love you dearly, my lifes service shall be devoted yours, prethee be kinder—How now! Who's that?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: My Husband! my Husband! for Heavens sake away, Sir, I'll wait you here to morrow.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Will ye, ifaith? will you not fail?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Upon my life I will not.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I'll trust ye then; adieu; a pox o' this Husband—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Come, Madam, 'tis in vain for you to wait longer: My Master I am certain won't come home to Night.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Go, get my Night-Clothes ready, I'll follow you—

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: THus, Sir, depending upon your care and secresie, I have told you my concerns.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, you shall never have any cause to doubt my fidelity.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: I believe thee, in troth—before George, thou hast an honest Face of thy own, that confirms it: Therefore, prethee give thy attention—I confess I am old—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O, Sir, not old.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Yes, faith, the Women think me so; and to deal faithfully with thee, I am somewhat above threescore—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, a small Age, that, Sir—for a healthy Man—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: But, I confess to thee, though I am old, I cannot chuse but love a Wench, as well as a younger Fellow. Well, before George, I know not what's the matter—but methinks I am never well without one.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign you came of a good Family, Sir. I shall laugh at this old Fellow—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Yes, the truth is, I came of a notable Generation; my Father and Mother were swingers—but let that pass—you know my Sneakie is about twenty one.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Much about that Age, in my Opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Yes, yes: nay I can tell to a Day her Age—but would you believe me Friend—I dare tell you, tho' to another I should be asham'd, when I am with her, sometimes, the arch Jade will play upon me strangely—she'll call me Fool almost at every Word. Ah, 'tis a witty Quean.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. Then it seems, Sir, she's angry with you sometimes; and how d'ee do to pacifie her?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p:
Why, you must know, Sir, I allow her a Hundred Pound a
Year, and that makes up the business very well.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: No faith we never quarrel—now, Sir for this reason I attempted the Charm you know of, thinking that would make me young and fit for her—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And yet to be never the better! faith 'twas ill luck.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: The better! nay, before George, I think I am the worse for't.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, that's worst of all, Sir. But pray come a little nearer to my business. What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: I'll tell you; the Story you told me to day of Welford has so tortur'd me—that I am grown damnably jealous; and I fear, I may have some cause if the truth were known; For I had certainly mauld him to night, if by some device or other she had not convey'd him away.

sp.speaker: Lov
sp.p: Very well. Sir.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: And tho' I cannot possitively say she did, I fear the worst—Now 'tis in your power to do me a signal favour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Command it then, Sir—you know I am your Friend.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: You can counterfeit Welfords Voice—I have heard you do it; you therefore shall go to her instantly, and personate him, she's in the dark, which makes me suspect she waits for some body, believing me absent—and to prove all, you shall court her as if you were him—and so find her inclination, then you discovering the truth to me—I shall know the better how to use her hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you must pardon me, if I refuse to serve you in this—I am sensible of the inconvenience, Sir. I shall not be able to contain my self—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Inconvenience! how, prethee?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you that are so jealous of every one, I have just reason to fear will be so of me, should I do this: I am resolv'd not to hazard the loss of so good a Friend about so trivial a matter.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Jealous of thee! what, of a Brother! a dear Friend that I have pickt out amongst Men to trust a secret with—jealous of thee! Why, thou dost not take me for a Fool, dost thou? Come come, no excuse, thou shalt do't—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It cannot be, Sir, what will she think? 'Sdeath this is the simplest Fellow—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: She think! why, she shall not know it, Man; there lyes the jeast, she shall be ignorant of it—and think 'tis he still; for you are to come in the dark—Now, here's my plot—by this means she taking you for him, will discover her Intrigue, and I shall know whether she is a Jilt or no?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, Sir—If I can do you any service, you know I want power to deny—Was ever such a Coxcomb—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Thank ye heartily, dear Friend, before George thou art an honest Fellow—well, I'll go instantly, and see if she's there—and then conduct you to her, and an hour hence—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, sooner if you please—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: No, no, not sooner: Well, have a little patience, I'll be with you instantly—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—This is the pleasantest adventure that ever Man had: and thanks to my Stars, my pains shall now be rewarded; for above these six Months have I laid plots, and studied daily how to obtain this Womans Company, and could never prosper; and now in a moment, when I least thought on't, to be brought to her Chamber; and by her Keeping-Fool, that has been jealous of every body: Oh, my Joys—methinks every Hour's an Age—till he comes—and then to bob Welford of his Mistress too, ha, ha, ha,—'tis a happy chance—Well, I see some Men are born to strange Fortune.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Where the Devil am I? this is the first door I found open, and I am resolv'd to enter, be it where it will. Hah—this Garden should belong to my dear Tricklove's Lodgings, by that Belcony there—ay, 'tis so—Now, if I could but contrive to make her hear me—I am certain she'd overcome all difficulties to let me in—but how shall I do it? Knock, I dare not, lest the old Fox should hear? Well I was a Fool to forsake my other Lodging—but when they cry how can you be so cruel, rather kill me then proceed, and the like, I have not the heart to touch 'em. But see, the door opens, and a Man is coming out. I hope she has heard me, and sent one of the Servants—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hist, hist, Come Sir—she's in her Chamber; and in the dark, as I told you: Therefore there must be some close business in hand—good Sir, make haste—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Oldsapp, as I live! Death, if he discovers me, I shall be murder'd—but I'll withdraw in time—I hope the darkness will obscure me—

div.stage: [Is going away, and Oldsapp holds him.

sp.speaker: Olds.
Welf.
sp.p: What shall I do—he does certainly mistake me for another, and I shall at last be discovered—whither, Sir, would you have me go?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Whither! what a forgetful Fool 'tis—why, have I not told thee already to my Sneakey—to my Sneakey Man; pugh, 'tis the modestest Fool this—go; prethee go; she'll do thee no harm, I warrant—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: No, I dare swear she won't.

div.p: Well, this is so quaint an Intrigue, that though I may be betray'd to infinite danger, I have not power to resist it.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Before George, I'll thrust you forward—if you will not go: why, thou art the dullest Fellow I ever met with—if Welford were here, he would not have been thus backward; a pox on him, he's ready at all times, would I had him here—'Sbud I'd give twenty pieces I had him in this Garden: But come away—thou art such a Ninny—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: What will become of me, I know not—but, let it be hanging, stabbing, drowning, or what 'twill, 'tis so happy an Intrigue, that I am resolv'd to venture, come what will on't—

sp.speaker: Trickl.
sp.p: WHat ever merit, Sir, you can propound to your self, had I known at first you were not my Love, you had not purchas'd my company so easily.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Madam, though I am not the happy Person you mean, yet I am one extreamly sensible of your kindness, and would willingly gratifie—but, what shall I do? you say the old Gentleman is just coming up; I hope you have more sense of Honour, than to betray me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I confess your behaviour has won so much upon my heart, that I should be loath to see you wrong'd here; but you'll forget me, when you are gone, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Never, Madam; don't doubt me—faith a Courtesie was never lost upon me yet; and that it should now is impossible: but hark, he's coming—for Heavens sake, let me not be surpriz'd

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, get you in there, at the end of that Gallery; there's a Door that opens into the Garden: but be sure you keep touch with the assignation.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: If I fail, wish me impotent, and that's plague enough for one Man.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
Welford, cloy'd with my love, has of late slighted me; but, now the happy means of revenge is come, and I am resolv'd to right
my self this way; since he's so dull and neglectful—

sp.speaker: Olds.
Welf.
sp.p: Was ever such a Night as this—if I come off but well, I'll have this Nights Adventure put into the Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: So, he's gone at last; 'tis such a bashful young Fool, that faith, once I thought I should ne'er have brought him to't—Well—I'll wait her—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: I have been groping up and down this half hour, to find the Back-Stairs she talkt of; but the Devil a Place, or Stairs, or any thing can I find to get out by—Ah, Plague 'o these Night-Rambles; the trouble a Man gets in finding his way home after 'em, is more by half than the pleasure he gets by 'em.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: 'Slife, he's come back again already, and ten to one will spoil all—why, Will, Will, is the Devil in thee, what dost mean to come away so soon—gad forgive me, you will not ruine my design, will you? get ye gone, get you gone, I say.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Death, what shall I do? this is the old Squire; he certainly takes me for some other; therefore I'll bear all patiently, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: She wonders I warrant, why he stayes so long; away, away—I never saw such a lump—no Life in thee.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: What a Devil he means, I know not; but I must go, to avoid further danger.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: It may be, thou canst not find the right Door again; come, I'll show thee—ah thou art a Novice.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: How durst you come back so soon, after I had shown you the way out, are you not afraid of the old Fellow?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: So—she mistakes me for another too—well—this has been a Night of Wonders—Why, Madam, do you not know me, sure the intimacy betwixt you and me, deserves not this forgetfulness.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p:
Oh Heavens! are you Welford! are you indeed! and have I then been mistaken? [aside] But why would you use
me so—why would you speak in that same tone to fright me?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ay, here has been another adventure: but this is no time for questioning—Hark, prethee my dear, let's have no disputes now, but go and see what the old Fellow is doing; for though he has been very kind to me to night, yet to say truth, I am not much in love with his company.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Kind! yes, great kindness indeed: his kindness was shown in besetting you—where, had not my care conveyed you hither, you had been murder'd by this time.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Thy care! why, prethee art thou mad? I tell thee he brought me hither himself—just now, within this two minutes; who he takes me for, Heaven knows, not I.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Ha, then I was not mistake—that was not Welford that was with me first—I'll seem ignorant, and recover all again—why, then you did not see my Woman that I sent to seek you?

sp.speaker: Welf.
M. Trick.
sp.p: Stay there then, till I come back—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Now am I very certain some adventrous traveller has been with her to night—and to finish his design made use of my name and quality—Well, for a night of Intrigues let this be put i'th' Calender—I have been exquisite at night-walking this seven years, and never met the like, What a pox the old Baboon should mean by his proceedings to me, I cannot imagine; suppose he does take me for another; why should he bring me to his Mistress! Well, let the Devil that knows all discover all—'tis beyond my apprehension—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Oh, what a quaking fit has he put me into! shall I never find the way out—I have gone I believe through twenty Rooms, and never the better—I got into a Closet just now, and groping about thrust my Hand into a Mouse-trap, and was pincht severely—and the worst is, the Devil o' any one there is up in the House to direct me—I must e'en go and awake her, and get her to assist me. This, by his directions, is her Chamber—hist, hist my dear; my dear—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Here, here; sweet, well—what say'st thou? where is he? hah.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: How now! what's this here? a Mans Voice, pox o'nt I am mistaken again—Damn'd Fate! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p:
If he be coming up, prethee convey me out; for I know he'll
never have patience. Prethee what is he doing of?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: What a Devil does he mean? hark, prethee honest friend shew me to the necessary house—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Death, have I been talking to a Man all this while? ten to one, one of the Servants—who has discover'd me, and stands here to watch—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: He's gone again; they are all Fairies sure in this House: Oh fortune! fortune! some deliverance I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: No way to escape! well, this comes of rambling. 'Sdeath, would I had been sighing at home, rather than sweating here.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: VVhere are ye? oh! ha, ha!

I have been to see for the old Gentleman, and coming softly through the Hall—found him sitting alone in the Porch: and I believe he has been there all this Night; but for what reason I cannot imagine.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: So, I am glad I found her at last—there let him stay if he pleases—But dear sweet Creature, shew me the way—for I have been rambling about ever since, and cannot find the way down—besides, here's some body in the Room too, prethee who is't.

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: VVhat curst luck is this? he come back again!—ha, I swear you frighted me—but speak softly—(who is't) why 'tis, 'tis—the Chaplain—don't disturb him—he always studies in the dark, 'tis his custom.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Sure I heard a whispering; now are they plotting together to cut my Throat, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Come, prethee let me be gone instantly; for if he discover me I shall certainly be murder'd.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Hah!—what's that, murder? oh these cursed VVomen; what dangers they bring us to?

sp.speaker: M. Trick.
sp.p: Follow me, Sir, and tread softly—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: VVhat, are they gone? nay then I grow chearful: a pox on't, what a Feaver have I been in?
If I can find the way out now, all is well: if not, 'tis but staying till she comes back, and then, I'm at liberty.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Lovel solus, clapping himself as if he were a cold.
div.p: DAM this old Rascal: what does he mean by making me stay thus long? sure he dares not do't to abuse me—and yet it may be so, for the cause of his bringing me hither is so ridiculous, that the truth is, I had not faith to believe it at first—my patience is quite tyred: And besides, the Air is so cold and piercing, that if I stay a little longer, I shall be mortify'd for any VVoman these three Days. 'Sdeath, am I thus baffled—I'll carbonado this old Rogue; a Dog, a Son of a VVhore, no one to affront but me—besides all my hopes of seeing that sweet Creature is disappointed—'Sdeath, I'll murder him in the next Tavern I meet him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This is the Garden, Sir; and yonder at the end of the walk, is the back door that leads into the Street. I dare go no further, least I am seen—farewell, Sir,—fail not to meet me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: I won't, sweet: so now there's some hopes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, yonder, I think he comes—I thought the old Fool durst not affront me so—harkee! Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: VVhat now? 'Slight! have I met him again?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Is it time to go yet, Sir, I thought you had forgot me, you staid so long.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: VVhat the Devil shall I say? how long have you staid, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How long! why by Heaven above this hour and half; come, come, Sir: dispatch, dispatch: if you stay a little longer I shall be very unfit for the service you intend me.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: This is not he, this is another; and a new adventure I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: VVhy dee not answer, Sir?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: 'Tis so: I'll banter him a little—Sir, the cold Air will season your complexion.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How, Sir? complexion!

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I have heard, the Switzers lye naked in the Snow to make their Skins the tougher: a politick Nation, Sir, and by my faith, 'I think hardly to be conquered—for take it from me, Sir, they are—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What a pox care I, Sir, what they are; art thou mad old Fellow? what dost prate to me of Snows and Switzers?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ay, but, Sir, the Nation deserves—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Damn the Nation, Sir; is this a time for a discription of it: prethee speak to me of the Present Affair: Shall I go to the Woman yet? what a Devil didst thou bring me hither for?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: For Air, Sir, for Air; 'tis now very delightful and cool—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I shall cool your Coxcomb, Sir▪ 'Sdeath shall I be baffled thus by an old Badger?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Not so old as you imagine; and since you are for that sport, have at you—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! I'm mistaken, this is not he all this while—but no matter—I'll take such an affront from no Man—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: How now! what Noise is this? hah, fighting in my Garden at this time of the Night—hey, within there—murder, murder; Thieves, Thieves; Rogues! Lights here; bring Lights—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You are still so tardy; why did you not come sooner? for now he's below i'th Garden, 'tis impossible to convey you out, but he'll see you—the best way is to cry out Thieves with me—and make as if you came to our aid, hearing the out-cry—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: No, I dare not do that, he knows my voice; I'll try if I can steal by him—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: How now! who's there?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Oh—a friend, Sir, a friend—Oh how I shake!

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh, Will. art thou come off undiscovered? that's well—before George this was carry'd handsomely now. Come, I'll show thee the way out before the lights come; and to morrow thank thee as the cause requires—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: My dear, my dear; Thieves, Thieves; call the Watch, there's Thieves in the Garden—

sp.speaker: Olds.
