sp.p: Where dove, where? There Will. there; that's the Door: Where are they, dove, where are they—go, go out—at that Door there—Lights—Lights—there, away, away—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: We have searched all the Garden, and can find no body.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: No! why then they have kill'd one another, and the Devil has fetcht 'em away—To prevent further trouble—for I'm sure I found 'em fighting—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, let 'em go. Come, prethee, my dear, let's go in—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: With all my heart—I'll smother my resentments all to morrow, and then I shall know all—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: SO; I am got off at last—and thanks to an unexpected chance with all my Limbs too—which, as my case stood, be little less than a Miracle. But for that he should conduct me out, that two hours before would have murder'd me, is a wonder past my apprehension: I confess I have been frighted, damnably frighted, that's the truth on't; but a pox 'tis nothing, when 'tis over: and I begin to think now, that there is no Fate that keeps an honest, drunken, Whore-master up the Wall—when the judicious, reserv'd, sober Fool, is thrown into the Kennel—Well, I am resolv'd—I'll pursue the Intrigue to morrow with my new Mistress; gad she's a rare Creature—and I hope her Husband is not so kind as he should be.
sp.l: In Modish Love, th' allowance may be small;
But Marriage, like a Miser, covets all.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: DID I not tell you, he would not come to night: I know a Man of his humour can no more forsake company he likes, to come to his Wife, than an Usurer could forsake a Purchase of Land when he has it for half the value.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I confess it vexes me; but had I been of the same humour, you know I could last night have been even with him.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Madam, here's a Gentleman below, that enquires for his Cozen; I desir'd to know her name, which he says he is ignorant of; and says, she is a Relation a-far off; but by his description of her, he doe • certainly mean you.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: 'Tis he; I knew he would not fail: go, bring him up; and prethee Cozen, let's put a trick upon him. Do you step into the next Room—when you hear us entred into discourse, and that he leaves you as a spy over me—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I'll personate it to the life; but the jest will be to hear what a company of lies he'll tell when I question him about his Visit—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—away, away—he comes.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Madam, tho' the Night to me has been as dark and comfortless, wanting the light of your Eyes; yet this joyful Minute dissipates those horrors—and makes me happy to excess; ah Madam, I have been—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Where? or what have you been, Sir?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Where? why in my Lodging ever since I left you—and what could I be but the most melancholy, despairing, restless, uncoath Creature in the World—I breath not as I did formerly, my Heart pants, my Eyes roul—all my Faculties are disturb'd: In a word, Madam—I am desperately in Love, and with you; have mercy upon me, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: But, what help, Sir, can a Woman in my condition bring you: You know, I told you last Night I was marry'd.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, and the memory of it brings me all the joy imaginable—for 'tis only a marry'd Lady that has the ability of helping me. My Disease is of that singular Nature, that all other are helpless and unnecessary—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: A strange Distemper indeed—but hush; here comes my Sister—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: A Sister! a pox, shift her off, Madam—she is not for our company.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: O! I dare not for my life, Sir; she's my Husbands Sister, and one set to watch me.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: A fine VVoman ifaith, the Devils in't if I miss both—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: A handsom Fellow, I swear—who is this Gentleman, Sister, a Kinsman of yours?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; a Cozen remov'd: speak for your self, Sir—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: A little out of the way, Madam; and hearing she was in Town▪ I could not pass by without giving her a Visit; I had ever a dear love for my Relation—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
A very good quality, Sir; and if I am not mistaken, a thing
very little in use amongst young Gallants; for they rather visit their Mistresses than Relations—nay the Wives; 'tis a strange World, Heaven mend it; pray are you marry'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and have seven Children; a pox on her—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: So, that's a sound one—now he begins—

sp.speaker: Soph.
Welf.
sp.p: Very well, Madam; the old Gentleman and I are very intimate—What a Devil shall I do?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And pray how does he?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: In health; in health, Madam—he's a lusty Man of his Age, Heav'n bless him—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: How, in health, Sir! he was dangerously wounded in a Rencounter, not above three days ago; 'tis impossible he can be well so soon.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: So, I am snapt▪ 'twas given out, a dangerous Wound, Madam, but 'twas only a scratch; a very slight business, believe me—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And his Son at Oxford, how does he, Sir, Mr.—what d'ee call him?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ay, what indeed?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Mr.—Sir, you can tell his name: Mr—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: What, Gregory?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Gregory! no: Mr.—Lord, 'tis strange you should not know his name!

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Know him! alas, I know him, Madam, as well as I know my self; but I have such a confounded memory—his name quickly; I am founder'd.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: She means my Brother Alexander.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Alexander! I was sure I was near it—why, he's the same brisk Fellow, Madam, he used to be—all Spirit—(pox on him, would he had been hang'd seven year a go, so I had scapt the trouble of finding out his damn'd name.)

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: 'Tis strange he should be so alter'd, he us'd to be of a very sober, morose temper—Then, I suppose, Sir, you know his Sister, Mrs Phebe.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ay, I have some reason to know her, Madam, if you knew all—why she has been my Mistress a great while—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: How, Sir, your Mistress!

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ay, the business was almost concluded on—I had like to have marry'd her about a Month a go.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Marry'd! why, Sir, you say you have a Wife already, and seven Children.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Death and the Devil—I had forgot that—I see a Lyer had need have a good memory.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, my Cozen, Madam, is a little involv'd in a mistake, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I believe he'll prove a salse Kinsman at last—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I find it now, this is a plot upon me—well I shall have a time—why then, the truth is, Madam, I am a damn'd lying Rascal, and have not spoke a word of truth—since I came in—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Madam, my Master is just come home, and I believe coming up.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Here, quickly take this Kinsman of mine then, and convey him down the back way—a word in your Ear, Sir—write me word when you'll come next, that I may be better provided—and so your Servant good Cozen.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: So, that's something however; to night about twelve, I'll not fail you—your Servant Ladies, your Servant—I'll see if I can have better luck in my Evenings Ramble—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: How does my dear, sweet, pretious Wife, hah? Nay, I know thou art angry now at my staying out last Night; but prethee consider, my dear, I had business—business must be done you know—come prethee let's kiss and be Friends.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: This kindness adds to my suspition; for, he's never kind to me, but when he has been rambling—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: An Infallible Sign—for, to you he gives only false Fire—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Come, what's the meaning of this whispering; prethee my dear don't mind her; she's as envious as a Nonconformist Parson, that has lost his Benefice.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And you are as false as an Accomptant at the Custom House—nay, if you out do me at a simile—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: 'Twas wonderful business sure, that could make you out all Night, pray let's here—what business?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ay, come, the business, the business.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: You know my dear, when I left you I went to visit Councellour Fee-Simple—to know how my suit goes in Chancery—and to have his advice.
sp.l: My dear, I must beg thy pardon for a little while, I must to my
Lords again; the Case is to be determined to Night.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: You'll stay till to Morrow again, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: No, no, I won't; I fear it will be somewhat late, but I am resolv'd not to stay all Night: adieu, my dear Rogue. So—Now to my assignation—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: There must be something in this: Lucinda, go and dog him.
sp.l: Still I must doubt; for he that weds betimes,
Makes Marriage oft a Cloak to hide his Crimes.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Fred. Col. Buff, and Oldsapp. Boy.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: COme, the Kings health, Colonel: There it goes.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Come round with't: Sir Fredrick, to you.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Faith, I did not think you had past through so many dangers, Colonel, as you say you have.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Ah▪ little does the World think, what I have suffer'd, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ah, the Devil and all; why, the Colonel has been kill'd three times, hast not old stump?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: That I have, Sir Fredrick, above forty times, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What, kill'd!

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Not down-right kill'd—but very near it, as near as you can thrust a Knife. Oh, I have scapt by Miracle.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: I think thou told'st me too, that thou hast a demi-cannon Bullet in thy Belly, didst not?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Oh no, no, 'tis a mistake, several Ounces of Pistol-shot, I may tell you, but no Bullet, Sir Fredrick; no Cannon Bullet, I remember an accident once at Plimouth fight; I was then one of the Dragoons in the Brigade that lay before the Town: The Battery being rais'd, Sir, I mounted—I had not been there two Minutes, but I received six several shots upon me; two went quite through me—and one sticks here in my Throat, pray put your hand here—feel.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Before George, here's something, that's the truth out.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p:
Ah, this is nothing—why, the Colonel was one of
the six that made a Dish of Tripe, of a pair of old Boots; and a handful of Gun-powder serv'd for Mustard to't.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Gun-powder! 'tis impossible; why, 'twould blow him up Man, 'twould blow him up—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: What, a Colonel blown up! a Colonel! I grant it might blow up a stingy Corporal; or such a Fellow: but a fat Colonel! ah, there's no danger on't.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Nay, by the Blade we have been put to our shifts, that's certain; but no matter, at the long run, we did our business well enough.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ay, I think your Consciences were asleep, that's the truth on't; the Devil had a kindness for you, that's certain; or else you could never have proceeded so; for you know, Colonel, yours was the wrong Cause.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Cause! why prethee, we had no Cause, we had Money; that's the Cause of a true Souldier—Money! Money—I serv'd beyond Sea too in the low Countries—I have travel'd in most parts of the World, and observ'd the Customs.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Oh, that was my delight too. Didst thou ever observe the Customs in Catalonia Colonel?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Oh curiously, Sir. I sojourn'd there some Months.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: And pray what Customs do they use, Sir Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Oh wonderful! wonderful!

Why, 'tis the Custom in Catalonia, for the Women to bear Children at seven—and to dye decently at eleven—and for the Men to marry at fourteen, and hang themselves at twenty one—a barbarous Custom—but 'tis for prevention of Diseases—

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, nay, nay, Sir Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Hush, thou shalt see me balder him—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Before George, that's the way to prevent Generation, as well as Diseases.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis a hot Country, and they breed accordingly;—the poor people that eat nothing but Thistles and Barks of Trees—'tis true produce but one at a time: But, your better fort that feed on March-pane, and Yolks of Eggs—will bring ye five—six at a Birth, more or less, according as they are in humour.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Good lack! well, this travelling is a rare thing: why, who the Devil could have believed this now, but you that have seen't.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Then near the Bosphorus, the back part of Thrace, live a sort of Hogs that are skill'd in Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hogs!

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ay; they are good Scholars, and understand the Sciences very well; but that immoderate Crime of Wenching undoes 'em.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Ah rots their Memories; spoils 'em; undoes 'em quite.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why what a strange thing is this; but why don't they marry then, Sir, why don't they marry?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Why 'tis thought they would; but 'tis against the Law, and your Hogland-Law is very strict; very strict—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Before George, 'tis very strange—but prethee Sir Fredrick be plain, are they really Hogs—or a sort of Hoggish-Men like Hogs?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Really Hogs—prethee ask the Colonel; Colonel, what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—a Banter, a Banter; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: There I was with thee, faith Boy, ha, ha, ha. There's news for thee; tell it thy Mistress, do, put the banter upon her; give her a balderno, do I say—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Phoo—before George, 'tis a very silly humour this, Sir Fredrick, a Man knows not where to find you now adays with your shams and tricks—gad forgive me, I hope you do not take me for a Fool, do you?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Oh no Anger, Squire; thou know'st 'tis his humour; he'll sooner loose his Friend than his Jeast; and 'twere to his Father 'twere all one—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Nay, pox, not that I care a Pin; but I speak only that we might have a right understanding betwixt us. Here, Boy, the tother Glass, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: By the blade, I wonder where the Lady is all this while, Sir Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: And so do I too; for the truth is, Colonel, the main design of my coming hither, was to see her.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Sir Fredrick, a Bumper—Prethee lets be merry and cast away care Man, come I've a little Utensil within shall give thee a Song. Within there, Ienny.

lg.l: Close in a hollow silent Cave
Young Damon sleeping lay,
Himself one hour from grief to save,
And from the scortching day—
He Celia lov'd, whose Fate and wit
Did every Shepherds sense controul,
Whose every hair was Loves soft Net,
Whose every glance a Heart did get,
And every smile a Soul.
But see the Balm Loves Monarch keeps
To ease a Lovers pain,
As he in that dark Mansion sleeps
It fiercely gan to rain.
Fair Celia wandring through her Farm,
A straying Lamb from hurt to save,
Which got she folds in her white Arm,
And glad to save it from the storm,
Straight slips into the Cave.
The drowzy Swain begins to smile,
To see his Heaven so nigh,
She doubts and fears; and all this while
The Lamb stands bleating by.
No Breath is left her to complain,
She now a Captive to surprize,
And fears approaching Ioys or Pain,
Thus at the mercy of the Swain,
The charming Virgin lyes.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What think you now, was it not well sung?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: By the Blade, 'twas a pretty matter, and has some relish in't; ifaith I like it well.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hah, Will, dear Son, thy humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A word with you, Sir! Sir Fredrick, pray give me leave; I have some business with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: With all our hearts, Sir—we were just going. Come Colonel, let's go; here's nothing to be done to Night—Hark in thy Ear.
We'll go seek out the Fellow that waits on her, and make him a little drunk, and the business is done.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Agreed, with all my heart; Squire your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Prethee, Will, what dost thou mean by this? before George I am an arrant Ass, if I can guess at it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Not Know my meaning: Come, Sir, I'll refresh your memory, since you are so forgetful. Did not you bring me hither last
Night, to go to your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Yes marry did I.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Very well, Sir: And why was it not done then? why did you not come and conduct me as you promist? hah—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you wag, you wag, will you flout; will you jeer your Friend—fie, fie—before George this is unkind: What you did, you did—I know well enough how things were carryed—and I am contented—but ifaith 'tis ill done to upbraid me with it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What, what's all this? But, Sir, I am not contented till I have further satisfaction—I tell you I did not see your Mistress all Night.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: No: Cause you were i'th' dark—Ah—you are a wag.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I mean I was not in your House at all, but stay'd expecting you at least two hours—and at last fought my way out with a Bully that I found in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Then in my Conscience I put him in, instead of you: for one I'm sure was with my Sneaky at least two hours.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It must be so—For I saw him come out of the House— [Aside. Pox on't what damn'd luck had I—Well, Sir, since I see, Sir, you design'd no affront—I am satisfi'd; your Servant, Sir. I have an affair to night; or else we would confer longer about this business—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Was ever such a mistake! 'Sbud, that I should be so blind too; not to know another Man from him? yet tho' I could not distinguish, ten to one she might—she has her haunts I find. Who's within there?
Sirrah, is your Mistress come home yet?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, here's rare doings; but I am resolv'd I'll be reveng'd on her however. Sirrah, go you to the Constable here at the Corner of the Street, and bid him keep diligent watch about my Door; and if any Persons attempt coming in, bid him seize 'em; go—begone—Now shall she be taken by the Constable like a Harlot as she is, and punish't, till she comes upon her Knees to acknowledge her fault, and me her superiour—

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Henry, Madam Tricklove, Pimpo and Cornet. Lucinda at a distance.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: NAY, dear Madam, let me wait on you home.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: That's his Voice: he's here, and a Woman with him: This is as my Lady suspected—I'll stand aside and watch—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: By no means, Sir; pray take my advice and be gone, least we are seen—but be not far off—and I'll not fail you.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: But how shall I know the happy Minute, Madam?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Thus, Sir, 'tis requisite I go to him—but lest Sleep should o'recome my Senses too—I'll tye a String with a Bell to it—which shall lead from the Balcony into the Street—and when you hear all still, come and ring that Bell, and your kind Conductress shall be ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ah dear, sweet—how shall I gratifie thee? Well, I'll be watchful—your Servant.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: They are all very still methinks, pray Heav'n he has heard no Stories on me to Night, and is gone to Bed: Sirrah, go and open the Door, you have the false Key.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Not I, sincerely, I was afraid to bring it—Oh Lord, will you never leave these tricks—never leave buzzing and whizzing about the World like a Flesh-Flie; by gadsniggs, let me tell you roundly, Madam, you are a greater Jilt than the Whore of Babylon, and have more tricks, sincerely—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What tricks, Sirrah, what tricks?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Why is not two enough; but that you must jilt them to make room for a third; sincerely, you are more unreasonable than a Country Parson—that thinks he never has Tithe enough, and yet deserves none—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Rascal, is this a time for your moldy reproofs: Sirrah, let me have no more lies; but go and open it, and softly too, you know the danger else—go I say—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: 'Tis well the Watch are coming—and that I am afraid my person may be in some dammage, for being in such lewd company, Pimpo should be refractory else, I assure you.
Oh! now does my Hand shake so with the sense of the Crimes you have made me commit to Night, that I am not able to find the Keyhole—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Give me the Key: Cowardise is a greater Crime than any, and that I am sure you have enough of. Cornet, what excuse shall I make? he's grown of late so jealous, that I'm afraid he'll never believe me—

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Ay, and all your Kinsmen have been sick so often too, that if you go to bring it off that way, 'tis ten to one but he finds you out.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh, don't speak of that: if he finds me out I am undone—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: This comes of caterwawling.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: So, 'tis open; Sirrah tread softly—I'll make him believe I have been within all this Night—and lay in another Room, being not well—and afraid to disturb him.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: So, he's gone in with her—here's your constant Husband: But I am resolv'd, for my Ladies sake, to spoil his Intrigue to night; it may be I may get ten Guinneys of him to hold my Tongue too; I'll try my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh, she's come, 'tis she, her Bully▪ has turn'd her off at last—'Sbud, have I nourish't this Viper in my Bosom so long for this—Where the Devil is the Constable and Watch now—Oh, I think I hear 'em coming, now for my revenge.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: He cannot for shame deny it; and to excuse his coming will be to no purpose, because she is a Woman of the Town▪

Hah, and as good fortune would have it, here comes the Watch too—This makes well I am sure for me, for they know him—and hee'l be willing to give any thing rather than be so disgrac't—Oh, the Door opens.

div.stage: Enter Oldsapp, and takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ah, Mistress! have I catcht you ifaith! this is your visiting, with a pox to you—Hoa—the Watch there—hoa—I'll order you now, Madam—I'll teach you to abuse your Patron—I will ye Jilt, I will—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Seize on 'em; seize on 'em; if they resist knock 'em down.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Thank ye, Mr. Constable—do so, take her away; Carry her to the Round-house; away with her—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I shall, Sir, and you too, I assure you; you shall even house together to Night—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: How's that? I too; what do you mean? why do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Know you! no; nor desire to know you; not I—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This was a design upon me, I find—but I'll fit him: Sirrah, when they are all gone, tye the Bell here, and then go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why, what a Devil d'ee mean; 'tis a mistake, I am not the Person, 'tis she here, this Jilt: Death, what's here, a stranger—what will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Sir, you may well be asham'd of this rudeness: Heav'n knows, I came hither only upon a message.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, come, away with 'em, away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hold I say; what are you mad? I tell you we are not the Persons.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ah, Sir—that shall not do: I was charg'd to seize on all Persons that attempted to come in at this House; if you are not the right, you may clear your selves to morrow, for my part I must do my duty.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Your duty! poxo' your duty—I think the Devils in the Fellow: I tell thee once more, 'tis all a mistake: This is my House, and 'twas I that sent that message t'ee, with design to seize upon a Jilt—that I have some concern with; but this is not she.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And pray, who is that Jilt that you have such concern with, Sir, hah—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hey day! what more Miracles? How the Devil got you in?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: In! what do you mean, Sir? is't not enough, base Man, to bring your Wenches home to the very Door here, and make the whole Town witness of your lewdness, but you must be jealous of me too? she knows here I have been sick a-Bed all this Night.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I can assure you that, Sir, and in a very violent Feaver this hour.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: This is strange! but where was she, I am sure she was not in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, I left that empty for you, and your Wench there.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: My Wench! before George I ne'er saw her before.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
Pray let me speak with her a little; Had you any business
here, Madam—I suppose 'twas you knockt at the Door?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; there came a Gentleman home with you that I am concern'd with, and my business was to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: How, a Gentleman! what a Devil then you were abroad it seems.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A Gentleman with me! thou monstrous Impudence: with me, that have been in Bed sick to death, all this Night! but this is your plot, Sir, to let her slander me, base Man as you are—I see it now.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: As I hope to be sav'd, not I—I am so confounded, that I know not what to think of neither side,

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Nay, if I am not mistaken; and if you are not the Lady—

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Oh, if she is not; d'ee mark, Sir, is't come to that?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ay, this is rare Impudence; pray Mr. Constable, take her away; o'my Conscience, this is some Jilt that owes us a spite, and designs to make a separation; but it shall not do, Mistress—away with her I say—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon for my mistake: Come, Madam, you must go—but for your Masters sake, whom I have the Honour to know, you shall have a Watchman home with ye—but pray no more of these Night-walks.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: This is very strange; but I must be patient—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Come, my dear, let's go in again; before George I am afraid thou wilt catch cold—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, this shall not serve your turn; and, though I am too weak now to express my Anger, never think I'll put it up so; I will have satisfaction I assure you, Sir: this was well-carry'd—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Satisfaction; now ten to one but I shall be duell'd about this business—I must put a stop to that; for my capacity of fighting, like that of loving, is I think, past the best now. But I'll watch her a little more. This may be a trick—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: They are all gone at last—and now to my Imployment: This Bell is to give th' Alarm to the Damsel when the Giant sleeps, and the adventrous Knight approaches; so, this will be a Guinney in my way at least to morrow.
sp.stage: [Hangs the Bell down from the Balcony.
sp.p: Hark—I think he's come already—'tis a little too soon; but, no matter, I think all's well, for the old Man is gone into his Chamber—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p:
I am afraid I've overstay'd my time, and made her wait for me; but the damn'd Constable and Watch, yonder, stood so directly
in my way, I could not get by 'em. 'Tis a witty Rogue, what a pleasant contrivance she had—ha, ha, ha. Well, little does my poor Matrimony at home think that I am a Batfowling—but she's ignorant, poor Soul, that's one comfort—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Never Man had such damn'd luck as I; The Devil sent but two prizes in my way all this Night, and neither of 'em worth hanging—Well, however, I have one plot holds; 'tis now neat the time I promis'd Christina, and I'll thither—How now? What's this?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Where the Devil is this String? a pox o' these dark, envious Nights; there's never any Stars out, when a Man has occasion for 'em.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: What's here? a Man! and an Intrigue towards. This I think is Oldsapps Window; ay—'tis so: Here's another Adventurer, driving into my Harbour—but, this shall prevent him—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Hah—are you at that sport; my Sword's as good as thine, I'm sure, and I think the darkness is equal—

sp.speaker: Watch within.
sp.p: Past twelve a Clock.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: 'Tis best for me to retreat, till the Watch be past—I shall know this Bully another time—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: 'Twas well you run faith, gad I had spoil'd your Intrigue else; but the Watch are coming, I'll stand close behind here, till they are gone.

div.stage: Constable and Watch cross the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: What is the meaning of this, sincerely if he should be kill'd now, and I lose my Guinny, 'twould be fine work.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What Noise was that? I thought I heard one whisper; the clashing of Swords—but 't may be, 'twas only the Watch passing by. Well, I'll make haste to Bed, and to morrow reconcile my self to my Dove—it may be I am misinform'd—and have done her wrong, I must know the truth on't. How now! what a Devil have we here, a String ty'd to a Bell
sp.stage: [As he's going he stumbles at the string.
sp.p: That hangs from the Window into the Street? I'll see what this means I am resolv'd, here may be another discovery; before George 'tis so: Here's another plot going forward, I'm certain on't—But I'll be even with her, for I'll watch—I'll see what this New Project means.

div.stage: [Pimp. stands close in the Corner of the Balcony. Welf. returns below.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: So, they are gone at last; and now to find this Bell that my young Gallant was speaking of; I am resolv'd to defer my Intrigue with Christina so long. This by the quaintness of it should be a plot of Trickloves; and I'll see what welcome I shall have, that come unexpected—oh here it is—now Fortune—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Some body pull'd the string, and the Bell rung—list— ha, again—ay 'tis some Rascal—and I'll be his Porter immediately—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh how I shake! oh, oh—Madam, Madam, we are undone, discover'd, oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: The Bell is taken in—a sign I suppose of her coming, so fall, all's well.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Death and Hell; discover'd again! curst fortune: Sir, Sir, sweet Sir, begone—begone, our Intrigue's discover'd, the old man's coming, away, you are lost else—Cornet, do you run out and stop him at a distance, till I have made up the business within, and then privately convey him hither, for I'm resolv'd not to lose him so.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Th' old Man! a good caution; and I'll follow it, tho', I see 'twas meant to another—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: The Coast is clear once more—I think the Devil and his Imps are abroad to Night, with an intent to hinder honest Night-walkers—I'll try once more—
Oh Heav'n! what the Door open, and my dear Creature ready to receive me? a thousand thanks to Fate for this blessing. Ah my dearest.

div.stage: [Kisses Oldsapps Hand, who leads him in, the Scene being chang'd returns.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ah Rascal—now I think I have snapt you finely. Within, Lights, Lights, Lights, bring the Musket and two-handed Sword hither quickly, Lights, Lights.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Surpriz'd! oh I am in an Ague, what shall I do? will my damn'd Fortune never leave me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! he has not heard me—but is come in! This is the most spiteful of all Minutes: However I've a trick left—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: 'Sbud, are you all dead? what hoa, Lights here, Lights.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p:
Never a Chimney, nor Window, nor nothing to make my
escape? S'death! catcht like a Mouse in a Trap.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why, when you lazy Dogs; when I say?

div.stage: Enter Tricklove with Pimpo, below, Night Clothes.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Do it well; counterfeit your self drunk, and feign as if you mistook him for Cornet, and five Guinnies are thine.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I'll warrant you: Five Guinnies! odsniggers, I'll venture hard for't; there, there's the Closset-Door; away, Sir, away—

div.stage: [Guides him to Trick. and goes and stands in's place.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why Rascals, Sons of Whores, will you never come? before George I'll make a Bonefire of ye: Drowzy slaves—come, Sir, [Enter Servants with lights: Gives a light into Oldsapps hand. Where are you? How, Sirrah, what makes you here—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: By Fortune, sincerely, meer Fortune: Prethee let me kiss thee, sweeting; odsnigs I'll lye with thee for this kindness.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Away ye drunken Rascal—but where, where's this Night-Walker—I'm sure the Door's lockt, he cannot be gone.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Prethee, dear Rogue, lend me thy Candle to go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Away, ye sawcy drunken Rogue; why Sirrah, are you blind, don't you know your Master?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: How, my Master! I hope not so—Well, if you are my Master, thank you for letting me in, sincerely—I'll see if I can find the way to Bed in the Dark, and so good-boy t'ee.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What a pox can this mean?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: So; I'll second this, it begins well: What still more disturbances! will you never be quiet? I wonder what the Devil you unty'd the Bell for—Oh my side—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What the Devil did you tye it there for?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What! old jealous Brains! I'll tell you for what: The poor Fellow askt me leave to go and be merry with some of his Friends; and because he should not disturb you, nor none of the House with his knocking to come in, I contriv'd that Bell, and order'd Cornet to let him in; and you must take it away, and make a bustle here for nothing: Ah you are a muddy-pate.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Why did not the Rascal speak to me then? before George, I took him for another; go get you to Bed again.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
No; 'twas your jealousie, your jealousie, ungrateful man;
Oh my side! my side— [Weeps. But come hither, I'll try you once more; and if ever you suspect again, I am resolv'd for ever to forsake ye—Mr. Welford has long courted me without any return: but to be reveng'd on his importunity, I made an assignation with him this Night to meet him in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You see what haste I make to him; and I had told you of this before, had you not vext me so to Night—Now do you put on my Night-Cloaths, and go thither instead of me; in my shape you may easily have opportunity of snatching his Sword—and then be sure to beat him soundly. And when you have reveng'd your self sufficiently—Consider, ungrateful Man, what reason you have to be jealous? Oh my side!

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Well, before George, thou art mine again; and this discovery has made amends for all, and thou stands as clear in my thoughts as ever—My dear, dear Rogue, prethee forgive what's past—Come the Night-Cloaths—for I'll thither instantly, I'll swinge him—faith—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To be jealous without cause, is the worst of Ingratitudes, but you know my good nature—Oh sick! sick.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Alas, poor Rogue—so, so I do in troth—well have but patience till I come back, I'll let thee see how much I think my self oblig'd—ah, a watching Rascal—I'll be even with ye presently—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; so, farewel threescore and three; and now to my frighted Friend yonder in the Closet—I am sure not to be interrupted these two hours—and when he comes back again, I'll tell him Welford's coming might be hinder'd by some accident—I'll wheadle him into a belief of any thing—but I am tardy: Now to my new Lover—I am sure he expects me—

div.stage: [She's going out, and Cornet comes and overtakes her.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Madam, I have brought the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What Gentleman? Death and Confusion, Welford! Oh Distraction! what curst Fortune is this?
He's the only Man I would have avoided; for he's as dull to me now as a Husband. What shall I do, I am at my wits end now.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Mr. Welford, what a mistake is this? by Heaven I thought it had been the other Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Madam, you sent for me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well the Devil has plaid his part, I have it once more—I did, Sir, and if ever you will oblige your self or me, do what I shall direct you—I have told the old Gentleman, intending to put a trick upon him, that I was to meet you in the Garden to Night; and he in my Gown and Night-Cloaths is gone thither and expects you: Now if you love me, go into the Garden, and as if you spoke to me, call him a hundred Whores and Jilts—for abusing so good a Man as Mr. Oldsapp, and at last beat him soundly. This will make him ever have a good Opinion of you, and our Intrigues hereafter shall be less suspected.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Ha, this will defer my other Intrigue with Mrs. Christina: But come, 'tis but half an hour lost—I'll do't. [Aside. Well Madam, I'll go and do as you have directed; but though I am the happy Man now—there was a Bell hung at your Window, not long since, I'm afraid for another—besides a meeting last Night.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Heav'n! how came he to know that! Oh I'll tell you more o'that hereafter: Go, go, you lose time—There is a Lover provided, and Marriage is going forward—I'll tell thee all another time—but prethee go and swinge him soundly first—do my dear, dear, sweet, hony Rogue, do— [Thrusts Welford out. So once more all's well; and in spite of the letts and hindrances that envious destiny could invent I am free: Come, Sir, you may come out now—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: On your Commands I dare do any thing; but this methinks is a little strange. VVhere's your Dragon?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah, gone, gone, Sir! blown into Air? Fie, fie; a young Gentleman and ask questions—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: I will no more: Come, let's go in, and laugh at him—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.l: To drowzy Souls Love shoots his Darts in vain,
But happy Joyes that VVoman does obtain,
That gets her Lover by her working Brain.

div.stage: Enter Welford with a Dark Lanthorn and a Battoon.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: WELL, if ever a beating did a Man a kindness; my old Gallant is oblig'd to me for mine; it has quite chang'd his Nature, and from a rough, waspish—rude unmanner'd Fellow, made him as mild, a well-humour'd, sweet-condition'd person, as a Man would desire to keep company with—Ha, ha, ha—He thinks I meant her the blows, tho' he felt 'em—and from that belief, calls me Dear Friend, and swears he shall never make me amends for his wrong Opinion of me; so that Intrigue is secure: Now, for my 'tother Mistress, this is the House, and I'll hide my Lanthorn, lest I am seen by some prying Puppy at a VVindow—Now good luck towards me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Hist, hist, come, Sir, come—

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Christina and Lucinda with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I had discover'd more, but the Constable and Watch hindred me. But hark, Madam, I believe Mr. Welford's come.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I know it; and therefore am resolv'd to be prepar'd for him: What-ever my Husband is, I am sure my Vertue was grounded on a better Foundation, than to be so easily o're-thrown—I'll cure his rambling humour—he shall find there are some vertuous Women. Is the Moor a-Bed?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p:
Yes, Madam, and looks more horrid than ever, for her Age and Ugliness are now plainly discover'd—she seems very well pleas'd—and says, tho' the World is grown ill-natur'd now; she
has known the time when she has been call'd a Foil to set a Jewel in—and been kist with appetite.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—she'll fit him rarely—how now Cozen?

sp.speaker: Soph.
Christ.
sp.p: Pish—prethee spare thy pity for a Subject: Now Lucy—be sure you carry the plot politickly—and tell him at first I am not well, and will have no company—and so by degrees consent to let him know I am in Bed—and telling him that's my Chamber, send him to the old Moor.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: The Jest will be to see how reform'd he will look in the Morning when he awakes, and finds the Devil a-Bed with him—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Nay, we shall have sport enough—but come, let's begone—I'll instantly to Bed and leave my Door open—that when my Husband comes, he may make the less Noise. Sure this will appear a proof of my constancy to him.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If he has faith, it will—but I am afraid he's an Infidel.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Come, away, away. Now Lucy, mind your business.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O Sir, I was just coming to you.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I am glad I have prevented that trouble: Well, where's thy Lady, my pretty Emissary, hah—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Sir, she desir'd you, by me, to excuse her to Night—for she's very ill, and is gone to Bed.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Not well—gad my Company shall make her well. Come, there's Money for thee, prethee let me see her.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Well, you will never be able to make me amends, when you know how I've imploy'd my wits to serve you—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Hast thou—and igad I'll not be ungrateful, for I'll serve thee too: I love not to sleep alwayes in a Palace: A thatch't Cottage, and a Straw Bed, is sometimes more pleasant to me, than Embost Roofs, or downy Couches—but to the purpose—how goes my affair?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: VVhy, Sir, my Mistress loves you—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: There's more Money for thee.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Extreamly, Sir, beyond all others.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: More still.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: And fills her Husbands empty Head with Scoffs and Fancies, hers being full of you.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: There's all I have—and gad were not my Pocket now empty, more yet were at thy service for that conceit; but come, which is her Chamber, tell me that, and I am thine for ever—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Sir, I dare not—her Chamber! marry Heav'n forbid: I hope you do not take me for a Bawd, do you?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: A Bawd! fie, no; a little harmless Emissary, that goes on Loves Messages for Charities sake—Come—I have another Purse for thee at home, prethee discover—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: In good truth I dare not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Nay, still a denyal. Come, no more on't, I'll stand between thee and whatever danger happens.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But I am so afraid you'l do some mischief or other to her—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Pugh, what mischief? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Well, that's her Chamber Door, Sir—but I'll be gone, I'll be no accessary—I'll have no hand in't—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: No, thou shalt not—come give me thy Light.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: A Light—gad forgive me—what d'e mean, Sir; is't manners think ye to go into a Ladies Chamber at this time o'Night, and disturb her with a Light?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Well, I'll have none then; pox on her she'll awake her presently with her chattering—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Just gone, and as eager as a Student at his Commons: he gave me all this—and I swear had he given t'other half Crown, I believe I should have relented—for I began to feel some Motions of pity.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, I swear I believe thee; but in the mean time you are a fit Jewel to be trusted—a Mercinary waiting-Woman is a worse sort of Creature than a common Strumpet; for she only forfeits her own reputation, but t'other first sells her Ladies honour, and afterwards her own, that she may be sure not to go to the Devil without Company.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But I hope, Madam, you see I am a Woman of better Principles—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I do—and for thy own sake am glad on't: But come, let's to Bed—

div.stage: Enter Welford with a Strong-water-Bottle and a shoe.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Sure I am haunted by Fairies, that lead me into Dens and Caverns, where none but Witches inhabit; gad I know not what to think on't—For going to begin the first Complement of Love to my Mistress as she slept—the first thing I laid my Hand on, on the Bolster, was this—which by the feeling and smell—I guess to be my Grandams Implement, a Strong-Water-Bottle: And ifaith a Man would guess by her look to Day, she had little need of Restoratives. But here's another that's worse—for steping back—I stumbled upon this—a Shoe I think; but if she owns it, tho' she is an Angel by her Face—she's a Devil by her Hoof—I am resolv'd to inform my self—come what will on't—I very happily left my Lanthorn in a Corner without—and now 'twill do me excellent Service.
So, now I shall see what manner of Female I ha got.

By all that's good, a Moor, as black as the Devil's Grandmother; and I find it now, this is a plot put upon me—this Woman is damn'd honest—but I am glad I mist my Witch of a Bed-fellow however—stay, now for a Project to be even with 'em—Here's another Chamber, the Door's open too—and I think that's her Gown upon the Table—'tis so—Fortune I thank thee—now I am sure I am right—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I cannot rest and let this trick pass upon Welford; methinks there's something within me, that taxes me with great Ingratitude: For, I am afraid, I love him more than consists with my quiet, which induces me to imagine him worthy of a far better Bed-Fellow. Why did I then consent to't? my Cozen's a marry'd Woman, and 'tis but Reason in her, but I swear 'tis Barbarity in me! the height of incivility; and I'm resolv'd I will not suffer it. I'll instantly discover the plot to him, it may be so good an Office may commence a passion in his heart for me too, and that I am sure would be very agreeable: Hark, what Noise is that?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, since you can act Daphne so well, you shall see that I can act Apollo too. I shall be too swift for you—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Help, help there; I am undone else. Help, help—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: All that shall not do—I must be so unmerciful to stint this Noise—and since I've ventur'd so hard for't, am resolv'd to try the difference between the old, the Devil yonder my intended Bed-Fellow—and Lady Venus, my now happy purchase—smile Madam—and bless your Fortune: Oh my full Heart, Come, come, I've not a Minute more to spare, nor have you to consider, nay no strugling, it must be so—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, a word or two with you first.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, she here! a plague, and double plague on opportunity, she alwayes jilts us most, when most we need her—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: This is a wonder to me, prethee how came the plot discover'd?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I know not, the Devil I think ow'd me a shame, and sought to pay it this way: But, I am glad thy care prevented it—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Madam; there's no going out—I am resolv'd to make better use of my good fortune, than by such a neglect. 'Tis true, I have no occasion for a Witness at this time, but since it happens so, I must fortifie my self as well as I can—come, come, Madam—Hey—what do I see Raymond here?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Iack Welford here, and at this time o' Night? Death and Confusion! what means this? How now, Sir, what business have you here with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: His Wife—gad I am in a fine condition?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Sir, answer me, and quickly—lest I force it from you another way; what, you design'd an Intrigue with her to Night I warrant, and mistook my House for your Ordinary in Durham-Yard.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I'll venture, this must do or nothing. How, Sir, an Intrigue with her—pray be no longer guilty of such a mistake, I assure you, Mr. Welford's business here is with me.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: With you?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: With me, Sir; and a business of weight too; I can assure you; for he has this Night given me a promise of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Death! what's this—Madam, what d'e mean, I know nothing of the business?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Next week say you, Sir—fie, I swear 'twill be indiscreetly to marry so soon—(a word more and you're undone!) No, no—I think 'tis fit we consider a little—a Month hence will be time enough; indeed, Sir, next week is too soon.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Faith and so it is, what a Devil shall I do in this case?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Nay, if he comes to my Neice all's well again—he has a good Estate, and will be a fit match for her—but gad I thought his business had been with my Wife when I came in—but see how Men may be mistaken—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Pray Uncle salute him kindly, do it as to one that is shortly to be my Husband—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: What Husband, Madam! gad I must not let this pass—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: What Husband, Sir? d'ee begin to recant already, nay then I suspect something. Come, Sir, repeat your Promises to her instantly before me—or my jealousie will give me cause to believe my wife was concern'd here—it will, Sir—if otherwise, you need not study I am sure, for she has six thousand Pound, and merits you every way.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Six thousand Pound! gad this is better than I expected, a pretty Lady too! hah—I think I need not stand out indeed—six thousand Pound!

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Come, what say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Say! why I say, Sir, if she has six thousand pound, I will confirm my promises to her, I'll marry her at a minutes warning.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: That was spoke like a Friend—let me embrace thee, and give thee thanks for making our knot of Friendship stronger by this Alliance—Come, my dear, let's leave 'em together; they have a thousand things to say, I know—and 'tis rudeness to hinder 'em; farewell—I believe 'tis near break of day—I'll—take an hours rest, and then Neice—I'll go to the Alderman, and speak to him to get your Money ready—(So, this gives an opportunity of visiting my new Mistress again, according to my promise;) Come, my dear, this plaguy business does always so disturb thee—but—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I swear, Madam, this was a cunning cruelty, I have not heard of—to challenge me un-arm'd, and take my Heart by surprize; methinks in Conscience you should have given me an hours warning.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If you think me cruel, Sir, I can release your promise: nay, would chuse to do't, rather than give you occasion to boast of my kindness—I know you, Sir, and am acquainted with your humour.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: I am glad on't faith—for, when I was as well acquainted with your person—who can imagine the blessing that will follow—In brief, Madam, I am resolv'd to pursue what is so well begun, and will marry ye indeed—for the present I'll leave you to consider, and go to settle some affairs of my own—but believe I would not loose the hopes I have in thee, nor the possession of the joys that are in prospect—for all the wealth o'th' World—

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Nor I—I swear—

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Table, Chairs, and Bottles of Wine.
Enter Sir Fredrick, Lovel, Colonel Buff, and Pimpo.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: I'L lay any Man five Guinneys upon my Bowls to day;

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Lovel, what sayst thou? wilt thou take me?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not I, Sir—but is she at leisure now, think'st thou? Come, thou art an honest Fellow, I may trust thee.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Sincerely I know not, Sir—I hope you take me for a more conscientious Person, than to have any thing to do in Womens Affairs. There's no Money stirring with him, he shall know nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Come, Lovel, take your Glass; hark you, Pimpo, I am your Friend—keep her Affairs from these, and let me know all—'twas I that sent for thee—when is the best time to wait on her, ha? softly, when, I say—come, I am thy Friend I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, ay; your Servant, Sir; a Friend quoth a—(he has no Money neither.) Well—there's a number of Consumptive Knights now a-days; good, Sir—do not tempt me: Sincerely, I am a Man of better Principles I tell you—and if this be the thing you sent to me for—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Dam him; this is a zealous Rogue—I'll banter him—hark'ee, Elubu bizeldoclaman—bila, shaw!

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Carlid donzal. pulin tack lillikaw—do prethee.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Do what, Sir; I do not understand one word you say.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he plays the wag—he does ifaith— Well, Sir Fredrick—you will never leave this humour—but honest, worthy Gentleman, pray a word with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Honest, worthy Gentleman; mark the Colonel's Complement: I warrant he has been studying all this morning for't.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Do not trust a secret in these slight Bottoms; they leak presently: mine is the same business—the Lady, the Lady—thou understand'st me—by the Blade she is a dainty one—and I think I am the fittest for her—hah—come—when is the time? serve me but in this—and if ever thou hast a mind to be a Souldier—I'll stand thy Friend—I'll do thy business for thee

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: So—here's another Friend—and consequently no Money, for 'tis a Maxim—that he that professes most Friendship to you, will be sure not to lend you Money—a pox I'll have nothing to do with such sneaking Fellows—not I—for like my honest Brethren the Quakers, though I am a Rascal when there's Money to be got sincerely, I'll be a Saint when there's none.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hah, Squire! what brought you hither this Morning? hah—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh! no more o' that, Sir; before George I am very sore about the Back and Shoulders—I'll tell thee what, Will. I was beaten last Night Man, swing'd confoundedly—ha, ha, Iack Welford did it—well say you what you will, I am confirm'd he is the honestest Fellow in Christendom—

sp.speaker: Lov
sp.p: 'Tis much to hear a Man say so of one that has beaten him—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ah—I'll say it again, and again—his honest beating has much oblig'd me—and I am his humble Servant in black and blue for't—things are clear'd Man—all doubts and suspitions vanish't—hah—I could jump—I am so merry—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Squire—prethee come hither a little.
I have in Essex a Mannor of Land, and I would know whether, Elblizzelmontablementa blisigonable—now you can tell—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What say you, Sir Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Why look you, Sir—my Land is—deelishable, &c. now you can give me information—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Of what? what a Devil is't you say? before George I can't understand you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hah, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Well, you play the Wag with me, I warrant—but no matter, I am in so good a humour now, that I'll take any thing; and if we meet at the Bowling-Green anon—the Glass shall go round merrily, ifaith—till when, your Servant, I have now a little business—

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Come, Colonel; shall we go and dine?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, I have some business must be done, pray excuse me.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p:
Now to make amends, for once I'll condescend to strain my Conscience for ye, therefore go and stand all ready at the Back-Garden-Gate, and I'll see if the Old Man be safe, and come and convey ye into the House, and bestow ye conveniently—and then he
she likes best is sure to have her company—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Rare Rogue! do this, and I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: And I—by the Blade I believe he's a very honest Fellow—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh is't come to that? a rare Wheel—go then, and be sure you miss not the hour—for I'll be ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee—a very honest Fellow ifaith.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a very honest Fellow—ha, ha, ha: Am not I a cunning Rascal now, by gadsniggs I am—For I will make all these that think to serve themselves in this business and fool me, fool themselves and serve me—By abusing them, I shall get my self into my Mistresses favour again, who I know hates 'em—They must be Ferreting—well—sure this is the most immoderate whoring Age that e're was kown: No matter Signior you fleece your self indifferently amongst them—Ha, ha, ha—o' my Conscience I have made up more wanton matches, than ever Mosely did—And what then? why 'tis my Trade, and the frozen Zealots will allow a Man to labour in his Vocation—Besides I employ but my Deputy.
sp.l: For since all Crimes with profit come off clearly,
'Tis Profit is the Pimp, not I sincerely—

div.head: SCENE Ultima.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: NEver argue to the contrary, for you shall stay and dine here. The old Gentleman is now in so good a humour, that I can pretend you are my Kinsman, or any thing—I am sure he'll not suspect.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Do not think my dear, 'tis possible for me to be weary of thy Company; but I fear some Inconveniences may happen which we think not of; besides I promist faithfully to come home to Dinner, and I have a Friend or two that will stay for me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You may if you please satisfie that with a Letter; make no more excuses, for I command you stay, and if you had rather serve a little insignificant business before obeying my commands, you may do what you please.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p:
No, thou hast Charms enow to make a Hermit obey, one
that never knew what Love or Beauty meant; but prethee did the old Fox suspect nothing—if he had come into the Closet where I was lockt up last night, what should I have done then?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He! poor sneaking old Fool, he never mistrusts when there is an occasion, but when there is none: For, observe this, your old, doting, impotent, keeping Fool—if ever he be jealous of his Mistress, 'tis so much to his loss; for she'll still augment it, and by that means get one of his Bags, or a snip of his Estate for her plot at last, the cause shall always fall on her side, and then he is sure to pay soundly for his jealousie, tho' he has never so much cause for't.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Why, well said; and ifaith, if I could bring my reason to dispence with any rules for Love and Intrigue but my own, I'd sooner take thine, than any Womans in Christendom—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: There's a Book within in the Closet will teach you more, prethee go fetch it.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: That I will, if it be only for the curiosity of knowing the Author—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Madam, though your last plot has reconcil'd me to Oldsapp, I am not yet satisfi'd in point of Love—I must know more of this new Rascal—and I think this a very fit opportunity.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Again interrupted, and by him too? why what a madness is this of you, Sir, to come hither to me at so unseasonable a Minute —tho' the old Man has retain'd a good Opinion of you, d'ee think 'twill not make him suspect afresh, if he sees you here alone with me—go—for Heaven's sake go, go.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: The old Man! why where is he?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hush! where is he—why there, in that Closet there—go, go: nay go I say—hark, don't you hear him?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Nay, now I am sure I've found you out—for I saw him not a quarter of an hour agon, go into the Devil Tavern—and I am resolved to see who inhabits that Closet before I go.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh Devil chance, taken thus! hah, you'r so jealous! let me go, and I'll open the Closet Door—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: No, no, Madam, I'll have patience—

div.stage: [Holds her, and whilst she is strugling—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Oh dam him, Madam, this is an insipid Fellow: he writes—Death, Welford here?

sp.speaker: Welf. Raymond!
sp.p: why could the Devil find none to affront me in this nature, but one of my own Tribe, a Kinsman—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: How, his Friend! what a mischievous plot is this!

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Gad, I begin to understand the plot now: So, Sir, I see you are the Man of Intrigue still: You were the person the Bell was let down for last Night—but you may thank Fortune you are to be my Kinsman, and that the value I have for this trifle makes me think her not worth my Sword, or else this should not pass so—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I am glad o' this, was it his Mistress all this while? pass as it will, Sir, all I can say, is, that I was ignorant you were concern'd with her, and if that is not enough to satisfie you, Sir—I wear a Sword as well as another—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p:
Well, the Devil did take his progress last Night, that's certain: but you may take her, Sir. [Oldsapp standing at the Door.
And though you boast your self beforehand with me, in winning her from me—I knew her first—there I was beforehand with you—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir, I have known her too—when perhaps you have been lockt out—since you go to that—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh, the Devil! what's this I hear? What, both known her!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Death—I am undone! here's the old Man: Nay, Gentlemen, be not so cruel to ruine me—do but second me, and I'll bring all about yet.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, what is't?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: And I, for thou art a damn'd Jilt, I'll be charitable to thee, thou shalt have one Cully left.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Mind what I say then: You known to her—fie, I wonder you are not asham'd to talk so; but this it is, when poor innocent Gentlewomen venture their reputation in such Hands. Now answer—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: VVhy, Madam, why should you speak for her, you know her not—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha! what's this?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: You are not concern'd with her, I hope?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I dare swear you were hardly ever three times in her Company, and yet like impudent Creatures you dare say you are known of her—Ah 'tis a wicked Age this.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Oh, they mean some body else; but before George, at first, I was afraid they spoke of her; and gad my heart was at my mouth—Dear Welford, your humble Servant; welcome ifaith—who is this Gentleman, a Friend of thine?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and one that will be very proud of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Before George, I shall be proud of his too: Sir, your most obedient Servant—Here, hey, Boy—bring half a dozen Bottles of Claret.

div.stage: Enter Lucinda, with Christina, Sophia, mask'd.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: See, Madam; there they are, and with her, I told you I could not miss the House.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: 'Tis so, Oh Heaven! is this the Fate of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Welford here too—if he keeps this custom, I find I shall buy his Loaf at a dear rate.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: A Lady speak with me, sayst thou?
Tell her, I am at her service—I hope some new adventure—

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Sir, I desire a word in private with you?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: In private! with all my Heart, Madam: this Room, I confess, is too publick for any business—if you please, Madam, I'll wait on you to your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: No, Sir, mine is a publick business—you will guess it so when you see my Face. Now, what think you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: My Wife!

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, since my Friend is entertaining your Companion, be pleas'd to give me the Liberty of making my address to you—faith I must kiss your hand—Death my Mistress!

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What are these Women, my Dear, dost know 'em?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Not I, do you think I am acquainted with Town Women? Rare Gallants! they have their haunts I see.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Is this your Alderman that was to pay the Money, Sir?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Nay, prethee sweet, I'll give thee a reason for my being here.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And is this your preparative for Marriage, Sir?

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Preparative! prethee, what dost thou mean? why that Lady there is my Aunt—I hope you'll give a Man leave to visit his Relations.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Your Aunt! yes; so that Lady was your Cozen once, d'ee remember that?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: Well; then in brief, we'll give you full satisfaction at home, but no more words of it here—you see we are observ'd; and 'twill be for neither of your Honours to make discovery: In the mean time, believe your Jealousie always gives you the wrong end of the prospect—but hush, more of that anon—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Sir, now I'll give you cause to say, I am a Man of Wit and Design; ha, ha, ha—sincerely I have plaid such a pranck, such an exploit—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: What, Sirrah! you are upon some new sham, are you?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p:
Sham, O Lord! when I talk of Wit—he talks of shaming:
Madam, pray do you be more credulous—and hear me. Sir Fredrick, Mr. Lovel, and Colonel Buff—you know have long lov'd you?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: You, I know hate them; and though I have been often solicited by 'em severally to bring 'em into your Company, I never did; but sincerely, to shew my duty to ye, I have now put a pleasant trick upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Hast thou! well said; prethee what is't?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir, you need not know; I am upon the sham, am I?

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Well, well, I was mistaken; but prethee, dear Rogue, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Why, I have brought 'em all into the House, and plac'd 'em very conveniently. One of 'em stands there in the Pantry ty'd up in a Meal-Sack—and another sits sneaking in a Corner of the Wash-house—hid between two stinking Half-Tubs clapt together—and th' other is i'th 'Cellar, all waiting for the Watchword. Now stand all close and be silent, and you shall see rare sport betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—faith so 'twill—Gentlemen and Ladies, pray stand close.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: First, for my adventrous Lover i'th' Cellar here—hem, peugh—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Is he gone, Pimpo—ha—is the old Foel gone?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir—Come, come up quickly—

sp.speaker: Lov.
Olds.
sp.p: Will be a great hindrance to your Intrigue; hah—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How! betray'd! Oh this damn'd Rascal—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—But sincerely, Sir, 'tis none of my fault; for you know I often told you, what a Cause without Money must of necessity come to.

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: You are a pretious Friend indeed; but I shall take care of ye hereafter.
How now! what's that makes a Noise in the Pantry. Let's see—Sir Fredrick!

div.stage: [Opens the Sack and discovers Sir Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Oh! I'm almost smother'd: Oh that Rogue! by King Ieffery, I am almost choakt with Meal—

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: within. Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Hark! there's another voice—I think.

sp.speaker: Olds.
Buff.
sp.p: Where is this Rogue? this Dog? I'll cut him into Morsels—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Colonel, you know you are my Friend, Colonel—ha, ha, ha—and are to help me to a place—ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Let him alone, 'tis a wag—but prethee how came this mischance?

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Why, Sir, the Rascal hid me in the Wash-house, between two Tubs—and I suppose you know upon what design; and hearing the whistle, making haste to get out, I stumbled head-long into another Tub full of Water, which I believe the Rogue had set there for that purpose; but I shall find a time—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—a Tub of Water—'faith 'twould have been hard, that you that have been in the Army where so many Bullets have whiz'd about your Ears, should have dy'd like a Rat in a Tub of Water—But Colonel—

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, no more, I am not in a condition now to answer questions; only this I'll say, I can resent such an injury, and so farewell—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.p: This was a pleasant discovery, faith Squire; but see what Love is.

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Sirrah, did my kindness to you, and all my promises, merit no better reward than this?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Why, sincerely you did not carry it well, Sir; for had you had but patience till the case and quiddits of the proposals determin'd, or to be made plain betwixt Sir Anthony and Sir Rowland, had been first fetch'd over with a whim-wham for the better contriving of the business, the Intrigue had been setled, fixt, ratified and confirm'd, to order or declare a nonsuit as to matter of moment, significant with all propositions that should concern and perswade you, touching the great Cham of Tartary, or the Grand Signior; d'e conceive me?

sp.speaker: Sir Fred.
sp.p: Impudent Rascal! what, a Banter too! nay, then 'tis time to hide my self—

sp.speaker: Olds.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—the bantring Fool is gone off in a rage: Well, Sirrah, for this piece of service, Sneakey and I here forgive your past faults—Come, Gentlemen, lets go in and be merry. Lovel, thou shalt go too; thou hast been treacherous 'tis true, but Love makes many a Man so: Come, I forgive thee—

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Wilt thou never leave this mad humour of intriguing, Will. sure Age will wean thee from it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
Olds.
sp.p: No, before George I'm of your Opinion; 'tis impossible for a man of Spirit to be old, especially if he has such a Cordial as this by his side; hah, little Pigs-nies? gad I can hardly forbear kissing her before company: Here's a Jewel Gentlemen—here she stands that is not only the most constant Woman in Christendome, but there's ne'er a Wife in all Europe has such honest principles—and so give me thy Hand, I'm thine for ever.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Put a right value on her then, Sir; for give me leave to tell you, Sir, such Jewels are very scarce now a-days—

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well, if ever the Devil sate brooding to do Mankind an ill turn, 'twas certainly in a Woman; They are made up of nothing but mischief: If they are Wives they Cuckold ye; if Maids they begger ye; if Whores they jilt ye: Every way you are sure to loose if a Woman be concern'd in your business: Well, did not Interest tye my Tongue, I could say something, but mum, let it rest, all will out one day.

sp.speaker: Olds.
Trick.
sp.p: Oh, without doubt, Sir, they see you have given proof of it.
sp.l: But to forge plots in an extremity,
Let every Mistress henceforth learn of me.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: LIKE some true Friend that makes a willing Feast,
And him he loves does still invite his Guest;
Although his Treat prove course, is sure to use
A hearty welcome, and a kind excuse:
So th' Poet fearing this his Case may be,
T' excuse the Play's Defects has chose out me:
But I, swear, am loath to venture it,
You deal as ill with Women now as Wit:
And like true Gallants of this wicked Town,
Debauch 'um first, and after cry 'um down—
Ah, happy were the former Antique Days,
When Love and Wit, were taught in Schools, not Plays:
When Formal Grandees priviledg'd the Creature,
Allow'd Intrigues, and call'd 'um Scapes of Nature—
When Plays would do, without Sing, Show or Dance,
And Criticks slept in Native-Ignorance:
But now, about the World they spread amain—
Like Numerous Weeds that choak the Prosperous Grain:
However, though I know 'tis 'gainst the mind,
Yet, Gallants if you please▪ you may be kind,
Prove so—or may this Curse your Torture be;
May you all live, till y'are as dull as he;
And all your darling Misses prove like me.
But if you change your damning tempers, then,
As Heaven knows I love kind natur'd Men,
May there inconstant prove not one in ten.
Not peevish—proud—bit mild and silent all▪
If our Sex has faults blame the Orignal,
For all our frailties came by Adam's fall.
